reviewText:
Did you like the first season? Then you totally should like this one.
The gameplay has not really changed; you still have to make choices throughout the entire game, and these choices will change how people see you; which will influe how the story will be told and how you interpret characters' behaviour.

I recommend this game, because it brings a really fresh breath of air to me; you must appreciate it just like it is: an interactive story-driven movie in which you are the hero.

Playing as Clementine, the innocent little girl from the first season, might sound wrong: what could a little girl do after all? But Clementine has grown older, she has seen some crazy ♥♥♥♥. She's now mature and has great decisions to make, depsite her age.

All in all, the game is an awesome sequel to the first season, taking into consideration what happened in the previous game, as if you were the writer. The graphics respect the tone of the comics very well; sometimes colourful, sometimes picturing the gruesome reality of rotten corpses and slaughtered people, sometime the simplicity of the rare happy moments. Talking about emotions, they are well shown through the narrative moments and through the events.

If you want to continue the awesome adventure you've been through in the first season, by all means, play The Walking Dead - Season 2!

reviewText: The Walking Dead: Season 2 is a point and click adventure game based on Robert Kirkman's The Walking Dead graphic novels. Season 1 gave us a hell of a ride on the feels train. Season Two now has Clementine taking the main role as the protagonist. She refers to what Lee taught her when she talks about her past experiences, which is a really important part of the story. It's what really links Season one and two together. Over the past few episodes of season two, the character development progresses one chapter at a time. The choices you make CAN effect the main story line, but some of these are small and won't set back the story at all. However, dire decisions where you have to choose between certain characters, whether they live or die, really adds the tension. When these dire choices happen, it will have you in a moment of slow-motion, then you have to act quickly as the decision bar runs out. The dialog is getting better and better each episode. However, I wish Telltale would make longer episodes once in a while. Sometimes they can seem short, but as they say; 'Time flies while you're having fun'. And Season Two so far, is proving that games don't need to be AAA, have groundbreaking graphics to be a good gaming experience. It's the story that draws us in, we want to find out what happens the next episode. We want to know how these choices affect our story and the characters themselves. Some characters will return from Season One and 400 Days. There will be twists and turns on this train track of feels, but Telltale does a damn good job!

Good game although not as good / memorable as the first one.
Many improvements have been made to this game from the first one. The HUD looks way better. There aren't as many bugs as the first one although I didn't get any achievements from the last episode. The biggest improvement is that YOUR CHOICES MATTER. The first game your choices had little to no effect in the game, characters you chose to save died at the same time, did basically the same things and overall didn't have any effect on how the story was told. This game it truly matters. And also, the ending I got (yes there are multiple endings, crazy I know) was on par with the first game's ending if not even better.

reviewText:
It's the sophomore slump for Telltale Games' The Walking Dead! Hurray, Clementine is back! And so's that guy from the first season! Also, all the zombies from the first season are back.

So I enjoyed it, but predictably I enjoyed it less than the first season. This is because the second season kind of didn't have a very consistent tone - the writing was not as strong this time around. The first season had a great hook - the zombie apocalypse was starting, everybody was still figuring out the Rules, everyone's become desperate refugees trying to survive in a world gone crazy, themes of parenthood, humanity, survival, all that good stuff.

The second season is not as great in the storytelling department. Everybody's figured out the rules, the zombies are relentless and they show no signs of stopping (even after two years in, they rot but not enough to do something like fall apart), and the writers are trying to catch lightning in a bottle again by showing how Clementine grows up while many of her compatriots fall apart from stress unconvincingly. This is partly because the episodes have been shortened from two hours to 90 minutes, but also because I think the writers weren't doing so great a job here writing the characters in a consistent, believable manner. Come on, you survivor ♥♥♥♥ers, if an 11 year old is telling you how badly you're behaving and you ignore that then maybe I don't want to save you guys from being zombie chow. Carver (the antagonist of the survivalist community that the group has escaped from) had great moments, but he was killed off too early in my opinion. I would have loved to see him wading through a crowd of zombies going straight for the group for the later episodes. And the ending is kind of ♥♥♥♥ed and could have used a little more emotional balance other than KENNY IS CRAZY AND JANE KEEPS POINTING THAT OUT, WHO YOU GONNA TAKE TO THE ZOMBIE PROM? OOPS LOOKS LIKE YOU'VE BEEN PUNK'D

Anyway, SOPHOMORE SLUMP but there's still these great, punchy emotional moments to be had by playing, and I still liked the story enough to not complain about the actual gameplay again, so I recommend it. I'm wary of how Season Three is going to turn out, though. It could be the emotional, weighty comeback that it needs (like a Return of the Jedi) or it could come home, stumbling drunk and fumbling through the napkins, reciting a bunch of drunken pablum about zombies before passing out on the kitchen floor (like a Superman 3).

reviewText:
**If you havent played the first game beware of spoilers**
Simply amazing!  This is the successor to the hugely popular Walking dead Season 1.
This time around you play as Clementine, much older and much tougher.  As usual from the start you are thrown into the nightmare the world has become.  Right away you find yourself making decisions and just trying to survive.
The character development in this game is slightly different to the first game, i suspect telltale made it this way to reflect the large time gap between this and the first game.  Basically people are much less trusting or to be trusted, because the world is a different place now right?

I found myself struggling to decide what to say and do and mainly got by on my gut feeling putting myself in Clems shoes, again this seemed much different to the first game because each character seemed emotionally numb after living in the zombie apocalypse for so long.  Each person much like the first game you feel is a real person, they make mistakes and they certainly have an opinion.
The quicktime events slightly changed at times in this game i wont explain it but i'll leave you discover that for yourself, they work very well im my opinion but take a few moments to get used to.
Storylines this time around has changed pace, it just seemed that with each and every moment things can change and the pace of the game certainly did at times.
As per the last game you find that decisions you made earlier in the game effect things later on, with every decision you make it can have a negative or positive effect.  I wrote a review for season 1 where i explained that i felt a deep connection to the characters, this time around it was pretty much the same and much like the first game i just didnt want the story to end it was so good.
With each chapter of the season you will make good and bad decisions its just how the game is, my advice is try just not to do the right thing but just try to become the character and decide for yourself, the story works best this way in the long run.

I cannot praise telltale enough for making these amazing games with the amazing storylines and character progression.

9.5/10 if you havent played these games yet do so already!  You don't know what you're missing.
Cant wait for Season 3!!!

reviewText:
If you enjoyed Season 1, you'll love Season 2. You play as Clementine, the unforgettable little girl rescued from her tree house by Lee in Season 1. Having the perspective of a young girl and making decisions for her is an interesting and welcomed change from playing as a grown man in Season 1.

As you immerse yourself and see her growth based on the decisions you've made, you realize just how different and refreshing it is to be playing as a child. It somewhat reminds me of Arya's change throughout the Game of Thrones books & show.

Though not required, I'd highly recommend playing the 400 Days DLC since you will run in to some of these characters in Season 2, and the choices you make in the 400 Days DLC (and Season 1) will be carried over into Season 2.

The interactive action scenes that require a near split second response happen much more frequently than in Season 1 and they are a bit more challenging as well, offering a comfortable mixture of gameplay.

PROS:
Slightly more polished and smooth graphics
More interactive action scenes
Clementines child perspective is intriguing

CONS:
Decision Selection:  If you played Season 1, you probably remember that your choices were displayed in a vertical list and you could either mouse scroll or use numbers 1-4 to select, aiding in reading faster and making decisions more easily and intuitive.
In Season 2, your choices are displayed to you in 4 huge boxes that span the entire bottom of the screen and you must drag the mouse pointer to select. This may seem trivial to some, and while I don't consider myself a slow reader, I still feel it  takes away from those split seconds that you have to make up your mind.  While I understand that split-second decision making is an important part of the game, I find the new, large, prettier" GUI non-intuitive and distracting.
I much preferred the "bare bones" interface from Season 1
date: where you could easily see your choices in one small area and scroll through with the mouse wheel (or numbers) to select a decision.\nIt is what it is and not a game breaker
recommended: just personal preference.\n\nMouse Speed: An option from Season 1 that they removed. You can't change the sensitivity within the game itself (seriously?).  Since there are more interactive action scenes
hoursPlayed: some which require semi-precise mouse pointing during shaky gameplay
voteText: I find it really silly that this option is not available in game and you'll need to change your mouse speed in the system until you find a sensitivity that's right.\n\nGlitchy Rewind Option: I honestly thought at first that Season 2 didn't even have a Chapter Rewind option because it took 2 separate 2 hour gaming sessions for it to just finally magically appear without me doing anything. Again
helpfulPercent: not a game breaker
votesHelpful: but why isn't this bug fixed after nearly a year and a half after release? There were quite a few times I would have liked to rewind and try a different scenario.\n\nDespite these complaints
votesTotal: I still rate Season 2 very highly and would recommend it to anyone who's interested."

reviewText:
The Walking Dead season 2 takes place 16 months after the events of the first season. You now control a 11 year old Clementine which makes the world feel even more dangerous since taking down a single walker takes multiple strikes because she lacks the strength to destroy the brain. It is a shame we don't get to play as 9 year old Clem and suddenly get a jump cut saying “16 months later”  with nothing else added on how she survived or what she went through when she was most vulnerable. That doesn't mean she won't be in danger though, as she will be receiving plenty of horrific injuries. Her voice is no longer high pitched and cute like in Season 1, she now sounds depressed after all the stuff she has been through. And since it has been so long after the outbreak most of the survivors are very selfish and jaded or just flatout insane.

Nothing has really changed from Season 1 besides the story and a few new inputs during quick time events.  There are much less puzzles and less chances to talk to characters while walking around. They will usually just repeat one line and tell you to do something which helps keep up the pace of the game but also has less time to flesh out the characters.  It makes sense that they wouldn't want to converse with a little girl but it comes off as a bit silly how dependent they are on her at times. This time around they focus a lot more on human evil and pull it off very well. You will frequently feel intimidated by the insane people and more so by the people at your side as they start to lose it. Which brings me to the choices. It makes since that most people will ignore what you want to do but when you do make a choice it feels a lot less satisfying than in Season 1. They just feel lazy and the outcome will feel the same no matter what you pick, making it feel less like a choose your own adventure game and more like a point and click game with occasional dialogue choices.

The game feels like it was rushed out before they could fine tune it to the quality of the first. Not that I'm saying it is a bad sequel though. I personally enjoyed it more than the first due to the helplessness of playing as a child. It is a very “fun” and tragic journey that I refuse to spoil here.  Not bad at all if you don't compare it to the original. Though one thing I just have to mention is that they make you sit through the credits that lists the whole staff and their pets five times. That's just unnecessary but at the very least they throw in some good music each time. Still if you liked the first season and want to know what happens next this is a very solid purchase that is every bit as emotional as the last season.

reviewText:
I finally got around to playing TWD: Season 2 (I always buy them once all 5 episodes are already out, screw waiting months in between each one!), and it was just as compelling as the first.

No Season 2 spoilers ahead. Beware of S1 spoilers if you have not played it.
Stepping into the shoes of the now 11-year-old Clementine felt natural after the departure of Lee last season. But she seems to embody him in everything she does, and Telltale gives you the opportunity to make ballsy and often heart wrenching choices the way you think is right, same as the first season.

One of the complaints of the first season is it's a tad linear. Don't get me wrong, it's an amazing game, but the dozens of decisions we agonized over in Season 1 all ended up taking us to the same ending anyway. It was disappointing to make a tough call, be curious what direction the other choices would have taken me, reload the save and redo the decision, only to find out I ended up in the same place anyway.

Season 2 rectifies the linearity of the first one, especially in the ending department. In fact, if Telltale continues with the Clementine storyline, Season 3 is going to be one hell of an undertaking, considering the multiple different places (and people!) you had the possibility to end with in S2. It's almost for this reason I feel a third season wouldn't pick up directly where the second season left off. Sure, there will always be the people you can't save, and I'd reload a save file only to watch my favorite character die a different way, but overall, I was happy in feeling my decisions had an impact on the outcome.

When reading through some other reviews, one thing a lot of players agreed on is not feeling as connected to the cast as the first season. I can definitely see this, and I do agree I wasn't as invested in most of the characters, and didn't care about many of their inevitable deaths (sounds terrible, but it's true). However, there are enough characters I did find myself caring deeply about. Those are the ones TWD centers on, and that's what's important.

To quote another reviewer, I miss Lee." I do too
date: but Season 2 does a great job in convincing me everything I did last season wasn't in vain."

-------Final Thoughts at the end-------

Gameplay
Just like the first game in the series(and most of TellTale's other games) the gameplay is a mix between point and click, puzzle solving, and quicktime events. The puzzle situations are not hard nor are they long which helps a story heavy game like this keep moving at a steady pace. Most of them are, find the item and use it on whats blocking you, or use items in a certain order. You can explore around most areas and find other things to interact with in the world and sometimes may find another way to solve a problem. Quick time events will happen during some cutscenes, but are not to bad to react too(lots of mash Q then press E)

For the most part the gameplay is your average point and click adventure game with the addition of quick time events.

Graphics
The art design is the beautiful cell shaded art that we come to know and love from TellTale. The levels and areas are well designed and gorgeous to look at. The characters are well crafted and fit perfectly into the world around them. Cutscenes look smooth on my medium spec PC and have no framerate issues, even my girlfriend runs this game smoothly on her low end PC.

Audio
Audio is well done and makes you feel part of the world whether it be the stumbling feet of zombies from the world around you or the sweet ambience sound of the forest. The voice acting is well done and the voices fit the characters they were chosen for. The emotion is made aparent through the voice acting.

Story
I'm not going to give any information about the story line here, I will simply explain how the story line felt. The story line flowed smoothly and you can see the concequences of your actions take place, however I felt like no matter what choice you made their was no real saving them"
date: they would simply just die another way soon after. Also after playing through the game I felt like something was missing
recommended: I felt I had no real connection to any of the characters
hoursPlayed: they kind of just came and gone. This has to be my biggest issue with the game
voteText:
this may have been because the story was not as intimate as Lee's and Clementine's was. I felt like TellTale just couldn't capture that same feeling in Season 2.

Summary
At the end of it all
helpfulPercent: The Walking Dead: Season 2 is a great game to pick up and play as it will take you through an amazingly well crafted story in a beautiful cell shaded design. Its hard to put down because the story keeps you engaged and you will find yourself wanting to keep going to find out what happens next. I would recommend playing the first season first as it will help you understand the storyline better and help show the changes made in clementine."

reviewText:
I was very excited about Season 2 when it got announced. Season 1 of Telltale's The Walking Dead was my favourite game of 2012 and I got introduced to the whole franchise through that game. Because of that, I've pre-ordered S2, which is something that I've never done with a Telltale game before. (I do appreciate my efforts for trying it out something new, playing the game from the start and waiting for the upcoming Episodes, but I also regret it a bit because of the waiting between Episodes)

Season 2 had a rough start, some really unmemorable characters and it basically lacked any central plot. Truth be told, I thought only Episode One was decent at best, while Episodes Two & Three and Four were actually between Good-Great and it wasn't until the Season Finale where I've finally said that the ride was absolutely worth it. But was it worth the wait?

In short, both yes and no. It was worth the wait because of all the crazy stuff we witnessed in the Season Finale, but it also wasn't worth it, because the overall Season had some really rough parts that could have been fixed with better writing. It's safe to say that the Season Finale, while it was incredible, it was also a bit too late" at that point. People's reactions with the entirety of the Season have been mixed; some liked it
date: some thought it was just filler.\n\nWhile I like Clementine
recommended: I still feel that playing with Lee in Season 1 was better. His actions had bigger influences on future events
hoursPlayed: while playing with Clementine I felt that none of the people I've met in the game considered me or my actions seriously. It also felt weird that many of adults relied on a little kid during intense moments.\n\nI also have to give credit to Season 2 for being more inventive and giving us scenarios that have never really been done in the comics and the TV show (for example
voteText: Walkers on the frozen lake).\n\nIt all boils down to this. Season 1 had better writing and memorable characters

reviewText: Telltale does it again with the second season of The Walking Dead and you already know whether you'll like it or not. I would say the sequel manages to be even grimmer than the first game primarily by making a child the main character of the story and putting her through some pretty dark things by the end of it. Although it does take a while to sink in that a group of adults is deferring to a hyper-competent child to get things done most of the time but then again this is a Clementine show through and through, whether by making us witness her character growth and making her the decision maker in contrast with the first season. Story-wise it's about another group of survivors, their circumstances and how Clementine fits into all of it, although it also heavily hinges on a returning major character from the first season and a LOT of the impact will depend on how attached you were to said character.\n\nThis will either be a major boon or major bane in the last episode which is somewhat weaker than the rest and leads to an, for me personally at least, unsatisfying ending. Another negative, aside from Telltale's traditional life long quest to remove more and more of the actual gameplay from player's hands, is the fact that most characters from 400 Days are used in a very expendable manner when a whole lot more could've been done with them.

reviewText:
Brilliant story telling game. Full stop.

...

Well ok, for a review it ain't worth it.

So, if you've played previous Walking Dead 1, you'll see this game has exact same graphic design, music/OSTs and gameplay. Copy paste, just different scenario/dialogue/characters (some are familiars like Clementine or Kenny). There's an annoying thing of credit scrolling after every chapter ends, though. Bearable, but mildly annoying.

Game's split into five chapters, each chapter will give you a brief review of how you acted on that particular act and compare it with other players. Game's not that long, like what, six hours at most? No replay value either, once you beat it, you'll get full achievements. Just maybe want to rewind some parts where you made choices that had different outcome of who would have survived.

The real shining point is its story. You'll still be forced to show your true color in a dire need. If it's your first playthrough, most likely it's YOU who YOU are if YOU were in the position Clementine is in. This is what makes Walking Dead good, you are immersed by the story and imagine what would you do from the bottom of your heart. You'll be very attached to the characters you play and meet in the game. Not many games do have this ability to engage their playerbase.

So what are you waiting for? If you've picked this up on previous sale, download it and play. You will really appreciate what this game has to offer.

reviewText:
An example of a good sequel. Crueler, more interesting and with tougher choices.

At first I was reluctant to play as Clementine, knowing that Lee taught her to be a good little girl with high moral standards which would be kinda boring. But in a year long gap between two season Clementine matured a lot and became tougher. Even though everyone says that she's just a child and can't survive on her own, she constantly proves them wrong and shows that she clearly adapts better to zombie apocalypse than adults. Can't say much about other characters in this game. Some are good-written, some aren't and some are killed before you can begin to sympathize with them.

And this brings us to the main flaw of Telltale Games' games - your choices do not matter as much as you may think. Yeah, sometimes your choice would lead to the death of some character but about 2/3 of them die anyway and you can't do anything about that, so if you play the game again you may find out that that one time, when you were desperately thinking should you rob a guy with medicine or not, does not matter - that guy is still being robbed, if not by you, than by your partner.

Gameplay-wise it's the same game, since there is no point in changing working mechanics of story-driven interactive movie. And once again I want to note an amazing soundtrack by Jared Emerson-Johnson which blends really well with storytelling and beautiful on it's own. A real shame Telltale Games still haven't released it or the one from the previous game for sale.

Overall it's a good experience, still better than TV series, season 3 when?

reviewText: After the amount of praise that Season 1 got, I honestly thought it would be really hard for Telltale to manage to do it again. I'm glad I was wrong. Season 2 takes off right after where you stayed in Season 1 and this time you play as Clementine. If you've played Season 1 and/or the 400 Days DLC, your actions will carry over to this Season.\n\nTelltale managed to keep the pace up on this one and I feel that this time, the decision making situations were alot more intense. This is one of those games that you can't really exemplify because by doing so I'd be ruining it for you. What can I say is that if you've really enjoyed The Walking Dead Season 1, I'm pretty sure you'll enjoy playing through Season 2, it has alot going for it and I'm eager to see how Season 3 turns out.

reviewText: Season 2 was an incredibly different experience from Season 1. I was incredibly emotional through Season 1. Cried my eyes  out after every episode. Could not play more than one episode in a day. For season 2, I played 4 episodes in one day and didn't shed a tear. No sniffles. No, that does not make me cold hearted. We follow Clementine immediately after Season 1 and follow her journey. Clementine is amazing. This is both the games strength and weakness. We all love Clementine. She has been through a lot of stuff. However, all the adults around her put way too much responsiblity on her, making all the adults in this game look incompetent. There isn't really a Lee/Clementine dynamic. There were characters that I liked, but I never felt a connection with them like I did in Season 1. I will still play a Season 3 if one comes out, just out of love of Clementine.  If you are interested in Clementine's story and willing to put up with some weak story and character points, its worth it. I found this flawed game interesting and intriguing enough to play through to the end, and hope for the best for the survivors. And their survival in the hopeful sequel to come.

reviewText: The Walking Dead remains an example of fine storytelling. I had hopes that this breakout series from Telltale would iterate, evovle, and build upon the formula. I imagine a story that we could each steer to our slightly unique destination. And why wouldn't they have the funds to do this given the success the first season. But it has not come to pass.\n\nThe first season gave us a hard road with small detours that ultimately led to the same conclusion. It never lived up to the promise of 'Mass Effect with zombies', but it compensated with some intense situations and choices which mattered - at least in the short term, over an episode or three. Sure, if you tugged at the strings hard enough, the illusion came crashing down, but you had the feeling that an honest effort was made, one perhaps tempered by realistic budgets. By contrast, the path laid out by season two is largely a straight line, with choices" often being resolved within the very same dialoge tree. Choosing the "Silence option" in conversation often results in the other character responding with a suitably vague response that would have adequately covered the other three conversational choices. The dramatic "end of episode" choice you make in episode 3 is revealed to have had almost no input into episode 4
date: being resolved in the first 30 seconds. And I have no reason to expect that the almost identical choice you make at the end of episode 4 will play out any differently. I am ameniable to granting the game a suspension of disbelief
recommended: but that doesn't mean you should take advantage of that. This violates the contract between player and game and you find yourself increasingly unwilling to give them the benefit of the doubt. You need to put forth a little more effort to make this more than a two hour cutscene. The end of episode "Important decisions" screens are telling - "Who did you sit with at dinner" is not an meaningful gameplay choice.\n\nSo I get what they're saying. There is no stable family group for Clementine. She is adrift in an unforgiving world
hoursPlayed: and making bonds with other characters is hardly worth the effort because everyone leaves in the end. And you fall into that rhythm along with her. It's easy to throw in the towel. "Jimbo will remember that" means little when he's out of the picture 20 minutes later. And when you have half an episode to make a connection to a character

reviewText:
Unfortunately, that’s really the extent of the effect you have on The Walking Dead’s narrative. Like in season one, picking sides causes people to react to you in different ways, but the plot still moves forward just the same. Decide to steal someone’s medicine or let them go; you’ll be in the same spot regardless of what you end up doing. Occasionally your choices will affect who lives or dies, but everything always ends up reverting to some kind of status quo. Moment to moment, The Walking Dead is thrilling, and it feels like your choices matter--examine it too closely and you realize that you’re merely given the illusion of choice. It’s no worse than the first season, but it ends up feeling more obvious the second time around.

Still, while the choices you make might not necessarily affect the overall story, they certainly affect how you feel about its numerous characters. I was worried that season two wouldn’t be able to deliver characters as compelling as the ones we got in season one, and that’s certainly the first impression I got when Clementine stumbles upon this new group. But over time, you get to know them and really connect with them as people. Luke attaches himself to Clementine as a surrogate big-brother, and the badass lone-wolf Jane teaches her how to survive at all costs. Even Carver, the megalomaniacal head of a budding utopia (and voiced by a scene-stealing Michael Madsen) feels relatable--his my-way-or-your-face-smashed-on-the-highway approach to leadership is extreme, but in the end, he’s only doing what he thinks he needs to do to survive in this harsh world. As in season one, season two’s cast follows a wide range of personalities, and each one is flawed in their own unique ways. They’re all capable of great acts of kindness as well as sweeping acts of betrayal--just like, you know, real humans are.

Unlike season one, season two completely sheds its extraneous adventure game roots. It doesn’t bog itself down pointless puzzles or fetch quests (people who remember finding batteries for a certain radio know exactly what I’m talking about). Rather, season two is constantly about forward momentum, as it propels you from one bleak scenario to the next. For the most part, this works in its favor--and whether you’re running from zombies or enjoying a brief respite, every moment feels deliberate. It really is a roller coaster ride of emotions (mostly depression), and Telltale has nailed the art of the cliffhanger in this series.

That said, season two’s pacing feels off. Major plot points are wrapped up by episode three, leaving the back half of the game to languish in this weird survival purgatory. There’s no real endgame--merely survival--and the last two episodes drift along aimlessly until the season's ultimate conclusion. The payoff is certainly worth it, as its exploration of the evils any of its characters are capable of finally comes to a head--I just wish it didn’t take so long to get there. Even with these pacing issues, season two is still worth playing, as there are some truly surprising moments that will make even the most hardened player reel in shock.

Season two also keeps its signature quick-time events intact, and if you hated them in season one, you’re going to hate them here, too. When you’re not navigating The Walking Dead’s myriad life-ruining decisions, you’re mashing buttons or matching on-screen directional prompts to avoid bandits or shambling zombies. Like the plot, these QTEs certainly feel like you’re doing something, and they definitely spice up the action, but they occur far too frequently, and your input is way too basic to be anything more than contrivance at best, and the red arrows have a tendency to blend in with all the action on screen, leading to more than a few frustrating restarts.

Even with its hiccups, season two of The Walking Dead is absolutely worth playing, with an interesting cast of characters and a narrative that is still sufficiently gripping despite its less interesting parts. It’s not quite game of the year material, and it doesn’t feel as necessary as season one, but Telltale proves that Clementine’s story is one well worth continuing.

reviewText: Season 2 enjoys an overall improvement especially in the storytelling and graphics department. I'm only 3 episodes in (since only 3 are available right now) but the tough choices have already piled up. It's also an added bonus that you get to meet interesting new characters. How are they interesting? It's hard to say without spoiling it. ersonalities are more spread out and experience is more common this time around. The game also shifts the focus off of survival by supplies to immediate threats. With that said, you can expect more action (sort of).\n\nSo far so good! I do hope that the last 2 episodes continue this awesome streak.
voteText: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I loved the first game.  Unfortunately, this one comes nowhere close to it.  It is no longer an adventure game meant to cause the player to reflect on how their values hold up when pushed to the limits (a stressful post-apocalyptic setting where ideals are never realized).  Instead, it is a 3D virtual novel with very little agency at all.  It was very rare that Lee ever did anything that directly conflicted with my agency.  However, Clementine's options never seem to fit how I want to react, and many situations are not only uninteresting, but simply convenient writing.\n\nAlso, although this is not an inherently negative aspect, each episode takes substantially less time to complete than the previous game, so on top of being unsatisfied with the content, I'm also getting less of it to judge it on.  Unfortunately, I regret my purchase quite a bit.  I don't feel down that I'm out $20; I'll gladly add that to them as extra payment for how great the first game was.  Instead, I feel cheated on the time I invested into the game.  No, you should not carbony copy a game when making a sequel, but this really isn't even in the same realm as the first game.
voteText: 158 of 304 people (52%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Another rollercoaster ride of emotions, this Season 2 imho is not epic and heart moving like the previous one, but the idea of seeing how Clementine's growing up and shaping her character after all that happenend to her in S1 was a perfect choice from Telltale.

The first episodes slowly introduce the new characters and relationships between them, then from the end of Episode 3, through EP4 and 5, everything speeds up, taking you to the final escalation and to five different possible endings. Choices you make during S2 are not determinant until the last minutes of EP5, and that's a shame because this gives you too little REAL decisional power, but it was nice to have a so hectic and variable ending. Now I'm curious to see what will happen in Season 3 and if the main character will change again.

There are also some plot holes here and there, things happen without explanations, some questions are left there without a real answer. I also found some new charaters to be really interesting and well built, others instead barely newsworthy. And well, sometimes Clementine is appointed with decisions and tasks too heavy for a small girl like her, not realistic and a bit forced by script and gameplay reasons, but fun nonetheless!

I liked Season 2, I recommend it to everyone who loved Season 1, however you need to know and like Telltale narrative and graphical style, so if you never played TWD or The Wolf Among Us, start from there before buying this one.

reviewText: Once you start, you can't stop playing.\n\nUnlike the first season, this one has less emotional feedbacks. The controls are less confusing and you get to play through Clementines eyes. This little girl is growing up so fast, she has been through hell and back and it's time for her to make the choices. It has a nice story but it's not as great as the first season and how it drags you in so deeply. Regardless, if you're a fan of the other season then you have to play this one too, and the others to come. I am purely addicted now, it's just a shame that I have to wait months at a time for new episodes :(

reviewText:
After how good Season 1 was, Season 2 had pretty big shoes to fill that it probably never could fill in the first place. But it's not too far off either. Season 2 follows up from Season 1 (woohoo for imported saves), though sadly 400 days seems like it was a waste of time after all. I want to say there is less action this time around, but that wouldn't really be true. Rather its that the change from playing as Lee Everett to Clementine that results in less fights for the player to get involved in directly, which is kinda neat in its own way. 10 year old girls aren't expected to do as much melee stuff as a 37 year old man would, though you still do some of that here.

There's also less adventure game style puzzles to do... alot less. Most of the gameplay here is dialogue choices and relatively brief action sequences, which almost puts this game into visual novel territory. It's a shame because there are far fewer opportunities for wandering around just chatting or interacting with the environment, which weakens the character development a bit for the new faces that don't get much time. It means that Season 2's episodes are generally shorter, but it also means that you spend less time wandering about and more time following the plot. A plot that is still quite good, though perhaps not as likely to bring people to tears as some of the bigger moments of Season 1 did. Nothing in Season 2 got that to happen for me, though the finale came close as you find yourself making rough choices that can give you very different endings (unlike Season 1, which ended the same way no matter what).

I'd say the high points of the season are found in Episodes 2 and 5 (which are also the longest episodes), with the other episodes mainly serving as build-up towards those bigger moments. I'm not sure where this series will go from here, but it seems very likely that we will see a Season 3. Whether that is with who ultimately makes it out of Season 2 or not (which has to consolidate the varied endings for this season), or if it is an entirely new cast, is uncertain. Until we find out... enjoy this one. It's pretty good. :)

reviewText: U odnosu na prvu sezonu, ipak blago razočarenje. Vidno kraće epizode, linearniji tijek zbivanja (izuzev grananja u posljednjoj epizodi), gotovo nepostojeća interakcija s okolinom i previše likova koji su na listi na odstrel u svakoj epizodi, nekako je ubilo prividni žar napetosti, težine odluka i smrti koje je donijela prva sezona. Samu igrivost zapravo je smiješno komentirati budući da je ovaj ♥♥♥♥ gotovo i nema - mnogo manje klasičnih avanturističkih dionica i još više QTE-ova The Walking Dead je još više gurnulo od pojma igre. Koliko god su primjerice u Heavy Rainu bile smiješne situacije gdje bi morao pomaknuti gljivu na kontroleru da uzmeš ručnik i protagonistici obrišeš leđa, barem se stvarao prividni dojam igre - ovdje se igra prečesto oslanja na neinteraktivne video sekvence i zapravo je najčešće jedina igrivost odabir jednog od 4 odgovora u dijalozima.\n\nIpak, mogu ovaj naslov preporučiti svim ljubiteljima ovog formata i samog serijala - drame i dalje ima dosta, likovi unatoč nedosljednjoj karakterizaciji pružaju dosta ljudskog šarenila vrijedno dubljeg istraživanja te u konačnici vrijedi provjeriti kako izgleda odrastanje jedne djevojčice u postapokaliptičnom svijetu.

reviewText:
The gameplay is more refined in Season 2, focusing on the game's strengths while reducing the classic point and click sections, which often broke the flow in Season 1, to a very healthy minimum. It is indeed a stellar interactive experience from beginning to end.

The story, however, suffered in Season 2 - the absence of the dynamic between Lee and Clementine hurts the game and similar bonds aren't formed. New characters the player is supposed to care for rarely live longer than half an episode.

The game is trying to show the impact this post apocalyptic world has on Clementine but is ultimately leaving the player equally jaded and emotionally drained. It's hard to tell if that makes the game successful or not ...

That said, despite its flaws, it still has some of the best storytelling in any modern game and should be considered a classic of the genre much like season 1.

reviewText:
Season 1 was Kindergarten - you won't be prepared for this!  INTENSE from the very first minute!

But let me make this clear: if season 1 didn't make you an emotional wreck yet, be sure to be masochistic enough to play season 2. It's amazing to follow and play Clem on her path facing new dangers every day, never knowing who to trust is the right thing or not. Stay careful and keep a close look at your characters, as soon as you start to like them they might be gone again already!

Yes, this season is more story-based, the choices may not be making that much differences in the end, but nevertheless you're shaping the personality of your very own Clem, never forget that!

Another plus is that it doesn't fail in bringing you back beloved characters from season 1 and 400 days, no one is truly forgotten in Clem's heart and memories.

#MyClementine

reviewText:
I'm writing this as a review for season 1 and 2. Yes, they're zombie games and those have been done to hell and back, but never one that has been done this well. These games manage to rip and tear at every conceivable emotion available to the player.

Much like many of Telltale's games these are separated into episodes and once you start an episode, it's hard to quit playing. These aren't your typical games however. They're more or less a choose your own adventure TV series. The game has a very simplistic UI and control scheme. Moving the mouse around will highlight areas of interest and you simply click once to interact with it. Action sequences are essentially quick time events and the only way to die is to fail these segments.

The beauty of the game is in the storytelling and how your decisions have an impact in later episodes. Many times throughout the series I found myself making some very heated decisions based on the feelings that the game evoked and I had to live with those choices. The game does a trememdous job of making you question if you made the right decision. I've actually lied awake at night on a couple occasions really regretting what I had done.

If you're not the type to care about storytelling, this isn't going to be the game for you. There's not enough substance in the core gameplay that would be appealing to someone that doesn't play games to follow a story. If that hasn't turned you away yet, the game does suffer some minor narrative issues. There are decisions you can make that really don't carry any weight, encountered more often in season 2, and ultimately the game moves along as scheduled.

TL;DR
If you enjoy good narrative based games, these would be hard games to pass up. The storytelling and your ability to react to the story are outstanding.

reviewText:
About The Game:
The Walking Dead: Season 2 is a story driven adventure based on the highly popular comic books & television series of the same name developed by Robert Kirkman.

The game starts off right from the end of the first season where Clementine has met up with Kirsta and Omid after the events of the original game.

From the very beginning you're brought right back into the great story telling & suspensful gameplay that you've come to expect from Telltale Studios, all is the same except for that it's now around about 3 years later and Clementine is no longer the child from the first game.

The Story:
This time around the story focuses on Clementine and her experiences in the world of The Walking Dead"
date: it's a long journey that is anticipated right from the beginning to the end & a worthy experience for all gamers who appreciate a good story.\n\nThe Story for "The Walking Dead" is a very long one and has so many different outcomes that it is really hard to write down
recommended:
the best i can really say is that it's quite the rollercoaster ride & i really urge you to just give it a go. Check out Youtube playthroughs to determine whether or not this is a game for you.

The Gameplay:
The Gameplay for The Walking Dead is the same as all Telltale games
hoursPlayed: it's designed really to be an interactive story more than a game
voteText: you push buttons that prompt your character to use different dialogues which determine many different things in which the character react to you
helpfulPercent:
think about you & what they'll do for you & solve puzzles in order to progress further in the story.

It's an interactive movie really you watch the game unfold while giving it mild plot changes during gameplay with the occasional Quick Time event that determines whether you die or not.

The Verdict:
The Walking Dead: Season 2 is a game that is not for everyone but it's certainly an experience for people who love a solid story or if you're a fan of The Walking Dead comics or TV series
votesHelpful:
or even if you're just a Zombie fan.

While this game has a very solid story & it's great to go through and try different things on other playthoughs it really just shines brilliance when you take the time to get to know each character and determine which characters you would want on your side in a real apocolypse scenario.

While the gameplay is pretty much just Quick Time Events it's 1 of those games where it works because it's not designed to really make you work
votesTotal:
unlike a Third Person or First Person game you are playing a game in this you're watching & creating a story.

This game also receives a 10/10 along with the first game because they're just so damn good. It is everything i expected for this series and nothing let me down.

It would have been nice to feel like some of my decisions really made a difference but it doesn't really matter all that much because the game is set on a very straight story that can't really be branched because of it's close steps towards the comic book narritive.

Do I Recommend This Game?:
Yes i do recommend it and it's well worth a play as i said throughout my whole review.

reviewText:
Season two also keeps its signature quick-time events intact, and if you hated them in season one, you’re going to hate them here, too. When you’re not navigating The Walking Dead’s myriad life-ruining decisions, you’re mashing buttons or matching on-screen directional prompts to avoid bandits or shambling zombies. Like the plot, these QTEs certainly feel like you’re doing something, and they definitely spice up the action, but they occur far too frequently, and your input is way too basic to be anything more than contrivance at best, and the red arrows have a tendency to blend in with all the action on screen, leading to more than a few frustrating restarts.

Even with its hiccups, season two of The Walking Dead is absolutely worth playing, with an interesting cast of characters and a narrative that is still sufficiently gripping despite its less interesting parts. It’s not quite game of the year material, and it doesn’t feel as necessary as season one, but Telltale proves that Clementine’s story is one well worth continuing.

reviewText:
Such an incredibly amazing story and series. Just like the first, Walking Dead Season 2 is just getting more and more depressing as it goes on. It's really counting on you, Clementine, to make quick choices and heartbreaking decisions during the horrible outbreak of zombi-... Uh ahem, Walkers.

Many, many, of the scenes in this game, including season 1, have made me gasp and scream. It's just so interesting to see how these characters have personalities that actually make you feel like they're real people, fending for their lives. Clementine is especially a great character, growing up since the first season, Lee in her heart, as she travels with a brand new group, and meets up with some old friends along the way, which was incredible to see.

The Walking Dead is one of those special type of games. It's definetley one of my favorites, and it's been an absolute blast to play. Clciking everywhere, fending for your life, and protecting and sticking by splendid characters that are all so fun to be with.

I absolutely can't wait to see what's in store for episode 5, and I hope it marks the dramatic climax of a great game that I've loved every hour of playing.

reviewText:
I liked this game much better than the first one. I'm going to say, this is still my second favorite choice based game I have ever played. I did like Life is Strange much better, but who doesn't like rejecting teenage boys? Jokes aside. This game was not spoiled for me like the first game; maybe I would have liked the first one better. I kept my word, and never trusted anyone. This was my goal for the game, don't trust hope and trust no one. The game has 4-5 endings, much better than only two like the first game had. I loved my ending, since I didn't follow hope, it was exactly what I wanted for an ending.

The beauty of the game is, you're a cute little girl, and no man is ever going to punch you. You can be a c***" to anyone you wish and watch them contemplate hitting you.

In other words
date: if you like the first game
recommended: buy it. If you haven't played it
hoursPlayed: buy the first game. You won't get gold class tickets for the feel train otherwise."

reviewText:
I'll get back to a more in-depth review eventually, but from what I've seen, if you liked the first one, you'll like this one too. It's as least as good as the previous game. Note that content is being released episodically, so you won't get the whole story yet.

2014.03.09: The episodes feel a bit shorter than in the first game. There's really not time to explore much or get to know the other people. The events and action scenes are great though.

2014.05.26: There seems to be fewer decisions to make, and overall the game more cinematic than interactive. It's just not quite on par with Season 1 on that front. However, the story is good and action sequences nice and gory.

reviewText:
One of my friends wrote a detailed review for this that convinced me to buy the game so i'll link a part of it here:
Episode One: Everything Is Remains

Unfortunately, that will never come to pass, and so let’s focus on what’s in front of us. Being created by Telltale and being based on a comic and TV series, it makes complete sense that the game is structured episodically (5 appears to be Telltale’s favorite episode number, the only time they strayed was Season 1 of Sam & Max) and belongs to the adventure genre, although not in the classical sense (aka mind-bending puzzles). This game is part of the new wave of adventure games in which the adventure is highly toned down and quick time events and quick decision making which heavily influence the plot rule. This new type of adventure game, clearly targeted at consoles as opposed to PCs, because consoles can’t Point ‘n Click (speaking of, Sony, isn’t it time you released Heavy Rain on the PC? I mean it’s been 4 years already, get over yourselves) is of course not intended as competition for oldschool-style adventures, but as an alternative to watching a movie (one episode has a movie running time).You can read the full review here[in2gpu.com].

recommended: chose a clear long-term goal within the first three episodes; this is different. Season Two is more dynamic and more of a "we have no plans
hoursPlayed: so make everything up as we go" type of deal. Don't let this fool you though
voteText:
as it is the choices you make that define the game.

Season One is a must play for this season to make an impact on your emotions because a lot of what you learned and what you experienced makes a difference. There's a minor connection to the 400 Days DLC as well but that is not required.

Overall this is fun. It's compelling to know that every decision makes a change in the future. Lastly

it would have been nice they had some sort of more keyboard support rather than just use it for movement and quick time events (ex. using the WASD keys to choose answers).

reviewText:
I have never, in my life,  cringed so hard in a video game (I won't spoil the scene in question if you haven't played it, but if you have, I'm pretty sure you'll know which scene I'm refering to). It's not that the scene was especially graphic or tramatic or terrifying. No, it was the connection I felt to the character (Clem) and the situation she was going thru. It was just brutal to not only have to watch it, but to have to participate in forcing her to do what had to be done. Just brutally emotinal.

At the end of the day, any game that can make me care that much about one of the characters is easily worth the asking price. You won't find a better story in gaming than what's presented here and in Season 1. If you don't own this yet, you owe it to yourself to pick this up. And if you don't own the first season yet, what the hell are you waiting for? This game may be a little light on the gameplay, but it's big where it counts; an emotionally gripping story that will make you genuinely care about the characters in it. It's like the best TV show or movie you've ever seen, and you get to be a part of the action.

Can't recommend this game enough.

reviewText: The Walking Dead is the pinnacle of modern day point-and-click adventure games. Its strongpoint is its dynamic storytelling and character development, which are tailored to player choice, not unlike role-playing games. This game creates characters better than most others, they feel more alive than any other game due to how responsive they are to your dialogue choices. Combined with the intensity of the plot, The Walking Dead is one of the easiest games to connect to, rivaled only by some of Bioware's RPGs. It's a definite must-have for any gamer, no matter how experienced you are. The Walking Dead is an interactive story, much better than the television show, and it's a fine demonstration of how good and personal video game storytelling can be.

reviewText:
REVIEW OF EPISODE 1 + 2 ONLY! (ONLY ONES OUT AS OF NOW)
I will update this in future.

If you liked Season 1, you should buy this right away, if you never played Season 1 it's probably best you play Season 1 first since it's so great and has a great story that continues into this and your choices from that game affect this game.

Episode 1 lasts like 1 Hour 40 Minutes. Episode 2 lasts about 2 Hours.
The story continues from Season 1. Clementine, Omed and pregnent Christa are trying to survive.
You play as the now 10 year old girl Clementine in a zombie (Refered to as Walkers/Lurkers) apocalyse.

In a series of events, Clementine is parted from Omed and Christa and meets with a whole new group and a famillar face, this game is so tense and has to be the most amazing game I've ever played.

The gameplay of this game is amazing and fits in very well with the cutscenes, during these cutscenes you choose what your character says and does and what you do Seriously affects the story, no crap just your own experience in the zombie apocalyse. The game outside these cutscenes takes the form of Point and Click, click on things, collect and click on more things but the game is so fun and the story is so interesting that this never gets boring.

The game runs better, a lot of new gameplay feautures have been added and the graphics have been given an amazing update from last year.

You HAVE to get this game if you played Season 1, don't end it there!
Amazing so far and there's another 3 episodes still to come!

reviewText: Amazing, I recommend this to anyone and everyone who has an appreciation for fine storytelling. Think of it as a mix between a Heavy Rain, Sam and Max, and of course, The Walking Dead. In this game your choices actually matter, they have an impact on what the rest of your game will be like, which is not something you see everyday. The cell shaded art style gives it a unique comic book feel, wish makes it stick to it's roots from The Walking Dead comic, which is nice, sometimes it can draw you away from the experience but overall it doesn't matter. Asides a few technical bugs, like characters disappearing and re-appearing, there is nothing that extremely catches your attention. The characters though, damn, playing as Clementine and choosing sides (or being neutral) between different characters throughout the game builds more of a relationship, and brings you more in-depth with how people are affected by the apocalypse. This is great so far, you'll see when you play it for yourself. which you sure as hell should do.

reviewText:
I need to start with the statement that Season Two is still good.

However, it's pretty far from the brilliance of Season One. Clem works well as a protagonist and will like to help shape her as she is growing older. However, the dynamic narrative that worked so well between Lee and Clem in the first season is lacking and never made up for.

The basic problem of the season is the lack of purpose. You don't have a major goal really at any time, you don't feel like there's a natural flow and so all the little events, personal drama, human loss and so on end up feeling meaningless. The other characters are either unbelievable (so stupid?) or just never fully developed before they disappear and this is in big contrast to Season 1.

So as I said, It's definitely worth playing but not nearly as good as the first (7/10).

reviewText:
While in the last game, we played as Lee, an intelligent, strong, adult male, this time, the playable character is Clementine, the young girl who we spent a large part of the last season protecting. Clem is still no more than ten years old, and the way that potentially changes how the player will interact with the world in this season is exciting. For her age, Clementine is certainly quite clever and strong, but the world of The Walking Dead is full of monsters, zombie and otherwise, and there's no question she's more vulnerable and less powerful than Lee was. One of the challenges of this is balancing between giving the player agency in the world without giving Clem influence she shouldn't have from a narrative point of view. This is going to have to be a very different story, and with the setup, it's somewhat hard to see how it will pay off the way the first season did, but we'll have to wait and find out.
In terms of gameplay, very little has changed from the first season. Most of the important interaction comes from dialogue choices, with QTEs and a few simple fetch quests tossed in to break things up. Like in the original, you will sometimes have to make some tough choices, and the game will keep track of how you choose, leading to slightly different situations. I sometimes miss the more difficult puzzles found in Telltale's earlier titles such as Tales of Monkey Island, but their more recent games seem to be going for a different type of genre, so it's probably best not to make direct comparisons. This is less an adventure game and more of a visual novel, albeit one that does a very good job of keeping the player within the lines while simultaneously making them feel like the story is their own. Perhaps things will change up in later episodes, but I don't really think they have to if the main concept is pulled off properly.
screen1136x1136-9
From a technical standpoint, well, this is an iOS version of a Telltale game, so things aren't going to be completely airtight. In particular, I should give a clear warning to people on older hardware. If your hardware was not officially supported but could run the first season in some fashion anyway, don't count on the same here. Things went pretty smoothly on my iPhone 5S, but I've seen tons of complaints from people on circa-iPhone 4 tech. Given Telltale's history, don't count on much technical support after the fact, either. One thing that did work quite well is the save game import. As long as you kept the first season on your device, you'll be able to import your final data for that. There aren't many ramifications in the first episode apart from the Previously" opening
date: but I'm sure things will come into play in less subtle ways eventually.\nFrom here
recommended: I'll write up a bit about each episode as they're released. As with the main review
hoursPlayed: I'll do my best to avoid spoiling anything current when talking about each one
voteText: but there may be spoilers for prior episodes as we go along. Tread at your own risk!"

reviewText:
This wasn't as good as the first season by any stretch of the imagination, but it's still a nice bit of storytelling.

The decision to make Clementine, a nine year old girl, the main character was bold but you get the sense that they didn't really know how to handle it for the first few episodes. Episode 1 and 2 are fairly bland and forgetable, but things start to pick up again when the character of Kenny is reintroduced and the stakes slowly build up. It never really finds the narrative flow that the first season seemed to have from the get go, but the last episodes (particularly Episode 5) have very memorable moments nonetheless.

As always, your choices in the game don't actually matter. You might save someone's life at one point, but that just marks that character for an unavoidable death somewhere down the line. A lot of the drama in episodes 2-4 rely on you caring about characters who are doing their damn best to remove themselves from the gene pool, but the sure knowledge that everyone you save is going to die anyhow at some point sort of minimizes that point.

Another problem with the choices is that they never seem to negatively effect you. In season 1 there were moments where a wrong choice actually got you killed (like telling that lady to put her ♥♥♥♥ing gun down in ep 2 of season 1 for instance), but that never happened in season 2 so after a while I felt pretty immortal. And that removed something too.

By the time they get to Episode 5 though, the writers figure out the kinks and kick things into high gear. It's an absolutely stellar finale. But the fact it took them that long to get to that point is kind of a shame, considering how much waffling the game did in the middle episodes.

Still, can't say I don't recommend it, in spite of the flaws. God bless Kenny.

Maybe season 3 will have an older Clementine.

reviewText:
I am not saying this game is perfect, but that i would recommend it
The story line of this game blew me away. Again, it has it's own style of graphics that belong to the game itself, and the story line completely showed up season one. I have to admit, the ending was really stupid, with the whole Kenny thing but i understand that it was just setting up the story for the next game.

Carrying on with the negative points, the protagonist of this story is around eleven, yet manages to outlive countless grown ups, including murderers who have killed people before (Lee). This was, in many places a point - and - click game, but it was very fun and fast paced whilst it was at it, so i'll let that one off.

Ultimately, I love the theme of corruption, with Clem trying to keep everyone together throught the story, whilst trying to make every one happy, and, alive. I can gaurantee that this game will make you laugh, and possibly cry thanks to the brilliantly made story line.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Telltale comes back with the second season of The Walking Dead and it does not disappoint! This season focuses on Clementine and how much she has grown up since the events of season one. She has witnessed some truly horrific events and it has changed her as a person. She is no longer the sweet little girl from the first season. She is willing to do whatever it takes to keep her and her loved ones alive. You meet a lot of new characters that you aren't sure if you will care about them or not. But as you get farther in, you get to know the characters better and you either fall in love with them or hate them. You still choose how the story plays off and some decisions will affect you in later on episodes. There were some very crucial decisions that I don't know if I could even make if I were in Clementine's shoes. Once again the writing and acting is top notch and never failed to entertain me. I was at tears at the end of the last episode and thought the ending had as much as a powerful impact as the first season did. There was a even a moment that made me cringe and it made it even better because it showed how hard it is to do things on your own. One thing I would take off for this season would be that I felt that some of the characters were wasted. I felt that they had more potential/development but suddenly they were just dead. Also, for most things when you make a decision, you basically get the same result if you were to make a different choice. But overall, The Walking Dead Season Two was an awesome experience and I will play it again sometime soon. If you still haven't bought this game, what are you waiting for? Stop reading this really long review and buy it!



9/10

+ Clementine's Story is amazing.
+ Crucial decisions leave you thinking.
+ Writing and acting is excellent.
+ Has a very high emotional impact.
+ Masterful last episode.
- Some characters were wasted.
- Diverse choices lead to same results.

reviewText:
From the people who grabbed your heart, pulled it from your chest, petted it and kept it warm just to lay it down and smash it with a ♥♥♥♥ing jackhammer, here is the second part (we all knew was coming) of the heartbreaking choice driven story. It goes above and beyond the standards of Season 1 by far.

The story gave us what we wanted and - yet again - keeps you wanting another game to play. This is just the start of TellTale's career as they will have so many projects (including Tales from the Borderlands and the absolutely fantastic Game of Thrones series' they're working on!)

10/10 - Watch/Play the first if you haven't already, then dive straight into this, recommended to anyone and everyone who's up for a fantastic and gripping story driven game!

reviewText:
tl;dr: generally okay season, but don't go into it expecting it to be as good as season 1.

The season isn't even done yet, we still have one unreleased episode at the moment, but I still feel like I know enough to say that it probably will not be worth it. Season 2 does not live up to the impression Season 1 left on me, and, as a whole, I think I liked the season 2 cast more. But it doesn't matter, in the end.

We complain about our choices not mattering in Season 1, because no matter what you do, everything converges onto one point by Episode 5 - Omid and Christa make it out of Savannah, and Lee sacrifices himself for Clementine. But never have I had so many of my choices invalidated in one episode than in Season 2. Having just played Episode 4 - nothing I did mattered that episode. None of my choices. Major characters dying without speaking lines, major characters dying in the most bogus ways possible, yet Telltale still tries to pass it off as shock factor.

And at this point? It's not. I played Season 1, and I know it's the zombie apocalypse and that people are going to die. Maybe that's meta gaming, but it's going into the game knowing exactly what I bought. I bought the game for the cast I knew I'd eventually come to love. The cast I knew I was going to die, but I knew I'd do my best to keep them alive. The cast I wanted to get to know, the stories of the survivors I wanted to hear. We get... almost none of that, here. In Episode 4, we get more about one character's backstory (whom we met in the previous episode) shoehorned into 90 minutes of gameplay than we have any of the other characters we've spent the rest of the season with. Only for that character to bow out, because she 'doesn't want to see Clem fall.' Ridiculous.

The writing is good, when it wants to be. When it needs to be, it falls flat. Characters completely change their personalities between episodes without us knowing why or seeing how - because they're off screen 75% of the time. There are significantly less hubs in Season 2 than there were in Season 1, meaning you barely get to talk to these characters when they are on screen. And when you do get to talk to them, you get one line, one subject, then it's done. But yeah, the story is still as emotional, but now I don't know if I'm crying at a character's death because I'm genuinely sad they're dead - or because I'm disappointed at the loss of potential.

At the time of this review, the day of Episode 4's release, I can say I'm not excited for Episode 5 at all. Let it come, let me cry, let it be over.

reviewText:
THIS IS A SERIOUS REVIEW, THIS IS NOT SUPPOSED TO MAKE YOU LAUGH

I didn't believe that this season was going to be better than season one, but man, was i SO WRONG. Yeah, i kinda missed playing as Lee, but playing as Clementine and seeing how much she has matured from the first season is awesome, and it's awesome playing as her. This Season has as much tear jerking scenes as the first one, and if there isn't the same amount, then it is more tear jerking.

In my Opinion, the Season started off a little bit slow, but every episode got better and better, then Episode 5 comes out and just blows me away. If you have not played the first season, I HIGHLY RECOMMEND playing it before this season, so you develop the relationship with Clementine and other Characters. Some Characters that are in the first season are back in this season, so prepare your ♥♥♥♥ for some tears.

If you don't have this game, it is a must buy, even if you aren't a fan of the TV series, chances are you will still fall in the love with this game. This is a game about building relationships with the characters and storyline, if you just like running and gunning games like Call of Duty, then this game isn't for you, but if you do love storylines and building relationships with characters, then this game is for you.

I'd give this game a perfect 10/10, the ending had me in more tears than the first one, and i can tell you, ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan in Episode 5. Last thing is last, if you read this full review, thank you for taking your time to read this entire thing, you are awesome.

reviewText:
Season 2 is not like Season 1. Let's get that out of the way now; the tone is much darker than the previous installment in the series, and much of this is due to the character whose eyes you see the world through. In Season 1, you play as Lee, a good man who made a huge mistake, who tries his best to protect his friends and, specifically, a little girl named Clementine. After an emotional roller coaster of a season, we have no idea who among the group survives, with the exception of Clementine, who has survived the ordeal of the finale to enter into a new and uncertain place. In Season 2, you ARE Clementine. During the whole of Season 2, you experience all the horrors of a world gone mad. However, there is no one to shield you from the darkness; despite still being a child, your Clementine has to experience the weight of adult decisions made in a nightmare world.

Season 2 is at times visceral, nihilistic, and genuinely painful to get through, especially if you developed any sort of affinity towards Clementine in the prior season. You'll meet all sorts of engaging characters, both old and new, but you'll often watch as they are quickly and brutally snuffed out, just another casualty in this constantly expanding hell on earth. The quicktime events compliment the narrative action well, though they feel more frequent and more urgent, as protecting Clementine from zombies suddenly becomes a direct survival experience. Rather than seeking to save someone from life as a member of the undead in a way that was so common in Season 1, you're often trying to save yourself from death while managing the fates of others.

Here's a brief spoiler: everybody dies. This game does a great job of hammering home the futility of life in this particular narrative world, both in the grand scheme of things and in the eyes of others, but it manages to make most deaths hit hard until it finally numbs you to the sensation of watching the life leave another character's eyes. By the end of Episode 5, I felt somewhat hollow and broken, as I was no longer able to trust my naturally altruistic intuition. During these episodes, you are betrayed, lied to, and ultimately left staring into the abyss as friends fall around you. I went from trusting the group, always following the altruistic path of the hero
date: to slowly descending into pure self-preservation, ignoring my previous instincts of group protection and doing the right thing" for the sake of surviving.\n\nThis season's story is well-told
recommended: and though it has some occasional weak points (Too many of the events seem overly emotional on the brink of pure manipulation
hoursPlayed: when a less heavy-handed approach might have done)

reviewText:
I feel like The Walking Dead Season 2 concentrates more on the storyline and character development than on the gameplay,interaction and the importance of choices that you make.Basically the game is less interactive but has a deeper story and feels more like a TV series.

The game follows Clementine after the events of The Walking Dead Season 1.Throughout the game you will be reminded about characters and events from the first game so it's very important to play that first to get the full experience from the second one.All episodes were good but I felt like things happened too fast.As I said,the interaction is weak in this game but the dialogue is much deeper and has more meaning so you will have to do less clicking and more reading.The last episode is the best by far,you will experience a roller coaster of feelings and then you will have to make choices that really affect how the game will end.And I'm telling you that you are gonna have a hard time making them.

The graphics of the game are the same so don't expect anything different,the movement mechanics are still kinda bad and feel  unresponsive but it doesn't affect the experience much.

This season rises to the level of the previous one but I still think that the first season was better even if the last episode of season 2 was the best out of the 10 of the series.

TWD Season 2 offers around 7-9 hours of gameplay and I'd say it's totally worth it to play it all and maybe replay it sometime.

reviewText:
Played as a child with a messed up childhood, just like me.

Pros
-Awesome unique gameplay
-Awesome Protagonist
-Character development for everyone in the game
-Intense Actions Squences and Quick Time Events
-Unique and cool graphics
-Characters connect together well/not so well
-Foreshadowing
-Good Dialogue

Cons
-Its painful waiting for each episode since each ends with a hook/cliffhanger
-It's painful to watch characters die, every character's death is painful even the clumsy and stupid ones.
-May experience a few bugs, I experience none

This game can make you happy, sad, angry, emotional and even cry, Get this game people the price doesn't matter its the experience that counts.

Only 1 question I want to ask, Where is the next episode?

EDIT: The Final Episode was released and I played it ( a few weeks ago) and now its time to give my final rating.

Rating: MUST BUY!!!, its basically like $5 per episode
Final Verdict 10/10

This game made many gamer around feel their inner emotions and successly made us attach to the characters either by hate (Carver) or love (Kenny).

reviewText:
If you've made it to the second game, you probably already know this is hardly a game at all.  More like a choose-your-own-comic-game.  If for some reason you stumble on this review having never played Season One or Season Two, I recommend checking to see if this is even your thing.  With that out of the way...

Season Two was even better than Season One, mainly because of the change of protagonist.  Not that there was anything wrong with Lee, but playing as an eleven-year-old girl is so much more interesting.  Clem is inherently and automatically so powerless in some situations, and yet incredibly powerful in ways you wouldn't expect.  That's one reason that makes this one of the more interesting narratives in all of gaming right now.  If... you call this gaming.

I can't comment on the extent of the branching story, because I have and probably will only play this once for a long while.  However, I imagine it's probably a fair amount of illusion of choice going on.  Nonetheless, this is worth your time.
