reviewText:
The Walking Dead: Season 2

Story
The story is very much the same one as the First Season, survive the zombie apocalypse but this time a crazy psycho called Carver will take you from safety and put you into his camp where you will attempt to escape from and find out that you and this mad man are quite alike, the other episodes are all about surviving and dealing with certain situations that you get yourself into. The new characters are not as likable as the Season 1 cast but this will make you have a harder time to decide who dies and who doesn't which makes more sense but this makes you think why do I care if Sarita dies for instance which is a little annoying but also better for the player when they have to make a tough decision. I have to say the episodes of best to worst go in this order.
Episode 3: In Harms Way
Episode 5: No Going Back
Episode 2: A House Divided
Episode 1: All That Remains
Episode 4: Amid The Ruins
btw this is my personal opinion.

Gameplay
The Gameplay is again a point and click adventure game but replacing the puzzles that took a long chunk out of the episodes with QTEs (Quick Time Events) which are done rather well they are definitely better than Season 1s.

Graphics
The Graphics are slightly better than Season 1 and have had a slightly more realistic look to the environment instead of the comic book style from the first season of The Walking Dead.

Final Verdict
I think that on a technical basis this is better than its predecesor but from a perspective of the story I think the first season has more shockers than this one.

The Walking Dead: Season 2
8/10

btw can't wait for Season 3 of this amazing game series.

reviewText:
SPOILERS

Short Version: An exceedingly good game let down by a couple of tiny gripes for me. The characters aren't as accessible, and the story moves too fast, taking the grim, tense slog out of the post-apocalyptic world.

The Walking Dead Game: Season Two was a game I awaiting with my teeth buried into my knuckles in anticipation, staring at the calendar for each episode of the five-part season. Prior to playing I had some serious fears for the game, not least that it was following The Walking Dead Game: Season One, which was most probably my favourite game of 2012, so well done Telltale for that. Suffice it to say therefore that Season Two had some huge booties to fill. For me there are two things that prevent Season Two from achieving this. One is something that I can explain myself to an extent, but it nevertheless does bite at my immersion-loving ankles, the other is perhaps the most surprising qualm I've ever had with a game. Enough build up.

Problem one. One of my favourite aspects of Season One was having a wealth of moments where your entire group was sat milling around by a broken-down train, or hiding out in a drug store. As Lee you could seize these moments of tranquillity and have a chat with all of your companions. Not only was there ample supply of these moments, but the conversations themselves were full of options so you could get to know your fellow man/woman/child/Ben. Having long, character defining conversations, where each character could say something to entirely change how you see them, for better or worse was one of the most engrossing things about Season One for me. It made each moment with them matter. They could reveal themselves to be a closet racist, or a snobbish elitist at heart, or they could show a depth of empathy and caring you'd not expected from them and never would have.

However, in Season Two, these conversation moments are whittled down, instead with a heavier focus on story (more on that later). While this could not necessarily be a bad thing (more story, more value for money etc) it means that I never felt much for any of the characters. While every death in Season One struck me in some way, characters came and went in Season Two like cars on a motorway. At some points I barely had time to remember their names and 'poof', they were dead or split off or otherwise departed. This meant that even as far as Episode Five people could die and my reaction was the same as if I'd just watched them scratch their chin. Given that by the timescale of Season Two, the zombie apocalypse has been cracking on for a good year and then some, so perhaps this less talkative batch of people works; everyone's realised that getting to know people well isn't a worthwhile investment. But it still makes the game feel shallow to me (by comparison with Season One, it's still gloriously rich compared with most, don't get me wrong).

That's problem that I can explain myself. Problem two though is a baffler. Due to the lack of slow, conversational moments to regulate the pace of the story, Season Two barrels through what I could have happily seen spread over Season Two and Three really. Yup, too much plot! So much happens in such a short space of play-time that, even though your character has gone through more ordeals than you can shake a dismembered limb at, I still felt cheated at the end. I finished the finale (which is a gloriously heart-breaking set of decisions that caused me a have a very restless night's sleep, so applause for you again Telltale, I'd ruffle your hair were you here), and looking back over the game, felt like I'd played the Cliff Notes version of the story, rather than the full text. There was so much potential for character development and building some horrific tension and decision-making into Carver's community. I'd happily have stayed there and let characters evolve and come to terms/blows with the situation a lot more. But the story seemed to feel the need to charge headlong onwards. Exploring Carver's world could have been fantastic, but it's gone now. Shame.

My main gripe story wise was that it became suddenly very linear. I saw an opportunity with Carver in Episode Three. My Clementine was by that point a cold, logical, unshakable zombie/bandit annihilation machine, and I saw the opportunity to stick with Carver. You want to survive, you join the winning side. To hell with the broken people you started out with. Life is for those who can keep it. But I was funnelled into making a decision I didn't particularly want to make, and this probably soured much of Episode Four for me.

However those are just two small(ish) issues that, because I'm a whiny git, I'm blowing out of proportion. The Walking Dead Game: Season Two is a fantastically made game, which slicker graphics, faster paced action and drama, and the same tough decisions, which ACTUALLY HAVE AN EFFECT on the outcome this time. I'm perhaps overly critical on what I'd consider issues that spoilt what would have definitely been my favourite game of 2014. If it had stayed a little truer to Season One, with a batch of characters I could get to know, it would have been a marvel of just how phenomenal a game could be. Instead, it's just very, very good. Given what it could have been, being an 8/9 out of 10 game is somehow a disappointment.

reviewText:
Season 2 is not like Season 1. Let's get that out of the way now; the tone is much darker than the previous installment in the series, and much of this is due to the character whose eyes you see the world through. In Season 1, you play as Lee, a good man who made a huge mistake, who tries his best to protect his friends and, specifically, a little girl named Clementine. After an emotional roller coaster of a season, we have no idea who among the group survives, with the exception of Clementine, who has survived the ordeal of the finale to enter into a new and uncertain place. In Season 2, you ARE Clementine. During the whole of Season 2, you experience all the horrors of a world gone mad. However, there is no one to shield you from the darkness; despite still being a child, your Clementine has to experience the weight of adult decisions made in a nightmare world.

Season 2 is at times visceral, nihilistic, and genuinely painful to get through, especially if you developed any sort of affinity towards Clementine in the prior season. You'll meet all sorts of engaging characters, both old and new, but you'll often watch as they are quickly and brutally snuffed out, just another casualty in this constantly expanding hell on earth. The quicktime events compliment the narrative action well, though they feel more frequent and more urgent, as protecting Clementine from zombies suddenly becomes a direct survival experience. Rather than seeking to save someone from life as a member of the undead in a way that was so common in Season 1, you're often trying to save yourself from death while managing the fates of others.

Here's a brief spoiler: everybody dies. This game does a great job of hammering home the futility of life in this particular narrative world, both in the grand scheme of things and in the eyes of others, but it manages to make most deaths hit hard until it finally numbs you to the sensation of watching the life leave another character's eyes. By the end of Episode 5, I felt somewhat hollow and broken, as I was no longer able to trust my naturally altruistic intuition. During these episodes, you are betrayed, lied to, and ultimately left staring into the abyss as friends fall around you. I went from trusting the group, always following the altruistic path of the hero
date: to slowly descending into pure self-preservation, ignoring my previous instincts of group protection and doing the right thing" for the sake of surviving.\n\nThis season's story is well-told
recommended: and though it has some occasional weak points (Too many of the events seem overly emotional on the brink of pure manipulation
hoursPlayed: when a less heavy-handed approach might have done)

reviewText:
Telltale's The Walking Dead video game series is my favourite part of The Walking Dead franchise, lots of people don't understand what makes it so great, or just assume it's not too good because they watched someone else play it on Youtube and think that's the same thing as playing it. However, they need to experience it for themselves - sure, at times the choices don't seem to matter a great deal regarding outcome, but the thing that makes the choices great is just how hard they are to make. You can tell just by the other players' choices at the end of each episode just how brilliant they are because the majority of the choices are split pretty close to 50/50 - getting close to that with every episode as the choices become harder and harder to make.

This is an immervise and dramatic interactive experience, there isn't a whole lot of gameplay in the traditional sense, there's some small areas to look around in at times, there's a lot of dialogue to choose and there are a few quick time events - but overall not a whole lot. I don't think this makes it a bad thing, it works, it's enough to make you feel like you're there.

For those of you who think that the choices don't matter, this game is a lot better than the first for choices. Not only are most of the choices harder, but they also do change things more. For example, a choice in the first episode makes the first 20 or so minutes of the second episode completely different. More people can survive depending on your choices, it isn't just a choose one or the other thing this time around. Also, the biggest thing of all is that there are multiple different endings to the season, all brilliant in their own right - not just one like the first game.

Please play this game if you care about storytelling in video games, because this is one of the finest games for that.

reviewText:
While in the last game, we played as Lee, an intelligent, strong, adult male, this time, the playable character is Clementine, the young girl who we spent a large part of the last season protecting. Clem is still no more than ten years old, and the way that potentially changes how the player will interact with the world in this season is exciting. For her age, Clementine is certainly quite clever and strong, but the world of The Walking Dead is full of monsters, zombie and otherwise, and there's no question she's more vulnerable and less powerful than Lee was. One of the challenges of this is balancing between giving the player agency in the world without giving Clem influence she shouldn't have from a narrative point of view. This is going to have to be a very different story, and with the setup, it's somewhat hard to see how it will pay off the way the first season did, but we'll have to wait and find out.
In terms of gameplay, very little has changed from the first season. Most of the important interaction comes from dialogue choices, with QTEs and a few simple fetch quests tossed in to break things up. Like in the original, you will sometimes have to make some tough choices, and the game will keep track of how you choose, leading to slightly different situations. I sometimes miss the more difficult puzzles found in Telltale's earlier titles such as Tales of Monkey Island, but their more recent games seem to be going for a different type of genre, so it's probably best not to make direct comparisons. This is less an adventure game and more of a visual novel, albeit one that does a very good job of keeping the player within the lines while simultaneously making them feel like the story is their own. Perhaps things will change up in later episodes, but I don't really think they have to if the main concept is pulled off properly.
screen1136x1136-9
From a technical standpoint, well, this is an iOS version of a Telltale game, so things aren't going to be completely airtight. In particular, I should give a clear warning to people on older hardware. If your hardware was not officially supported but could run the first season in some fashion anyway, don't count on the same here. Things went pretty smoothly on my iPhone 5S, but I've seen tons of complaints from people on circa-iPhone 4 tech. Given Telltale's history, don't count on much technical support after the fact, either. One thing that did work quite well is the save game import. As long as you kept the first season on your device, you'll be able to import your final data for that. There aren't many ramifications in the first episode apart from the Previously" opening

reviewText:
Season 2 of the Walking Dead starts off very well, episode 1 really got me in terms of emotions. I especially enjoyed episode 2, however later episodes get a little boring and repetitive. The final episode makes up for it though.

The interactive parts have been nicely improved since the first season, but there's also much less exploration you can do. There are some tough decisions to be made and consequences to deal with, which really affect the story and leave you wondering if you made the right decision... as once again, people's lives depend on you.

I really enjoyed playing this one, it might not be as truly amazing as season 1, but if you liked the first season, it's a must-play. Some games can really mess with your emotions, this is definitely one of those that you won't forget.

reviewText:
If you've made it to the second game, you probably already know this is hardly a game at all.  More like a choose-your-own-comic-game.  If for some reason you stumble on this review having never played Season One or Season Two, I recommend checking to see if this is even your thing.  With that out of the way...

Season Two was even better than Season One, mainly because of the change of protagonist.  Not that there was anything wrong with Lee, but playing as an eleven-year-old girl is so much more interesting.  Clem is inherently and automatically so powerless in some situations, and yet incredibly powerful in ways you wouldn't expect.  That's one reason that makes this one of the more interesting narratives in all of gaming right now.  If... you call this gaming.

I can't comment on the extent of the branching story, because I have and probably will only play this once for a long while.  However, I imagine it's probably a fair amount of illusion of choice going on.  Nonetheless, this is worth your time.

reviewText:
The Walking Dead: Season 2 is an epic drama encapsulating the life of a little girl called Clementine. The game includes difficult choices that ultimately lead to dangerous consequences. However you play it, there will always be hard decisions that require a lot of attention.

This incredible Telltale game carries on from the previous storyline of Season 1.

I would definitely recommend the game to anyone who has played Season 1 and wants to give it a try,(however if you are thinking of getting Season 2 first, I wouldn't because the gameplay of Season 1 will ultimately affect this gameplay,) personally I bought it during a sale, when it was reduced to £4.99, and I feel as if this game should be worth £15.00 on steam instead of full price of £18.99, but that's just my opinion.

There are 5 acts in this great game, however Act 1 and 2 didn't really impress me, the gameplay seemed slow and the decisions that needed to be made were relatively simple, and didn't come at a huge cost. However Acts 3, 4 and 5 were much better, with a better more adaptable storyline with more action and more difficult decisions.

Personally I played this game quite passively and tried to stay out of combat too much, whilst trying to make friends with everyone and not get in their way, however I couldn't do this for the whole game as some decisions required me to choose 1 side.

The improved gameplay from the first Season also made it stand out more and the Main Menu and UI was improved from the previous season.

I finished the game within a week of buying it, and although it may be a short playtime, it makes up for in gameplay.

Looking forward to Season 3 and hopefully it will be as good as the previous 2!!!

Overall I give this game a 9.1/10!!!!

The only fault of this game would be watching the credits after every Act, as it gets a bit repetitive!

SPOILER ALERT: Lee will be met again sometime in this playthrough!!!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
My expectations were set extremely high for this game because of The Walking Dead season 1, Season 1 was my game of the year and easily makes it into my current top five games of all time.

Telltale followed up their masterpiece with another work of art, a rich story driven game, beautiful visuals and once again; near impossible decisions.
The walking dead season 2 is set just a little while after season 1, you play as Clementine in this survival story.

Clementines character is really well developed and right from the get go you will feel strongly attached, especially after the events of season 1.

This game is a must buy for anyone that has played season 1 and if you haven't played that then you should definitely add it to your wishlist.

Overall

Pros
+Amazing story writing
+Great voice acting
+Thrilling and exciting
+Beautiful visuals

Cons
-Episodes still seem rather short

reviewText:
I for one love The Walking Dead: Season 2.

Definately worth the purchase! The storyline is definately the reason I keep coming back for more with beautifully developed individuals, personalities, situations, choices and plot progression.

(( BEFORE YOU PURCHASE: It would be well worth your time and your money to BUY and PLAY the FIRST game before Season 2 . The choices you make in the first game carry on through to this game! - If you don't, the choices from the firstgame are generated randomly, so its worth buying the first for the emotional connection to the characters, the tough choices you made and seeing the direct consequences of those!))

Alittle different to the first game, also a firm favourite game, in terms of the game interface, instead clicking on the option boxes rather than scrolling through the choices. A little odd to begin with but I found it extremely easy to click back into.

The graphics are definately easy on the eye and again, my favourite artstyle in a game for a long time. (And it mirrors the Grahic Novels of The Walking Dead. Lets not bring up huge collection of artwork and books from the series that is threatening to cave in the floorboards of my room... haha...)

The choices you make, the visuals and the audio is fantastic and credit must go to the entire developement team!

Overal, I definately believe people must try this game! If you prefer games such as Call of Duty, Battlefeild or anything in that style in online multiplayer, then it may not be your go-to choice but if you are anything like myself you will like this game.
If you love games with character, plot and consequences, this game is definately for you! The characters reach out and touch the sections of your soul that are usually reserved for close friends and family, especially when you have played the first game!

I'm not one to demand, but go play this game! Haha!

Till next time, Can't wait for Episode 3 to hit the store!

~Ree

reviewText:
The Walking Dead: Season Two had a tough job as the first season was simply phenomenal, but actually manages to be a solid sequel.

This time you control Clementine, and the story takes place roughly a year after the conclusion of the first season. The decisions you made previously and on the 400 Days dlc will affect the story. The structure of the game is similar to the previous one, but with a more modern UI and slightly better graphics, while retaining the comic book graphical style.

While I feel the episodes are a little bit shorter, it's still a matter of quality over quantity as the story is very engaging, with some decisions having a big impact in it. If you liked the previously season you should definitely get The Walking Dead: Season 2!

reviewText:
in The walking dead season 2 we played as Clementine.
Clementine is now eleven years old and one of the most badass female character for her age.
What i like about this game is the way telltale connect the walking dead season one story with this one with such detail.
i mean..... when Lee said a word in season one it can affect the season 2. it's just amazing how they keep that detail.
The walking dead season 2 is pretty much like the first season.
I feel like that this season's episode is shorter and we can't interact much with the environment.
but still...... the story is great as usual by telltale and the character development. And as usual.... i care so much about the characters in this kind of game.
Like i said in my review on season one.... this is not a first person shooter zombie game or that kind of thing. This is a point and click episodic game.
some of you who doesn't like this kind of game might find this game to be boring. But i said this game is AWESOME

10/10 for me

reviewText:
Spoiler/剧透预警
行尸走肉第二章：
Everyone  is ♥♥♥♥♥ or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ except Clem and Kenny.
最爱:Kenny
无论kenney做错了什么，无论他的暴脾气如何，无论他如何怪异.在第一部里面，是他修好了船。第二部里面，是他修好了卡车。
Kenney他其实就是游戏中的Rick. 这个顶天立地的男子汉，敢爱敢恨.第一部里面失去了老婆孩子，仍然坚强的活着. 第二部里面失去了新的爱人，情绪几近崩溃，最后还是去照顾那个孕妇(♥♥♥♥♥). 最后孕妇（♥♥♥♥♥）死了之后，kenney自然而然的承担起照顾孩子的责任. 最后Jane居然把孩子藏起来考验Kenney，Jane不明白人性经不起考验，这是多么stupid，所以最后她被kenney杀死，我觉得她罪有应得. 而Kenney，最后为了Clem和孩子，放弃自己进入营地，真是感天动地。果断选择和kenney一起。个人感觉是完美结局。Kenny作为一个男人，孤独的男人，他承担的太多，最后被几个♥♥♥♥♥，♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 各种judgement，如同Jane所说，那个什么狗Mike，俄国boy还有那个情妇背后议论kenney，你们几个垃圾有什么资格。屁都不会，Kenney干掉了黑帮头子，kenney是团队的支柱。
下面开始判刑：
最想他们死而不能死的：
1.俄国boy，根本就是个脑残玩意。从clem跟他说，我是个孩子，能别用枪指着我吗。这狗比无动于衷。就知道这是个垃圾。于是，后面kenney几次要毙了他，垃圾团队不听，终于酿成大祸。
2.Mike，这个叛徒。你放了俄国boy就算了，还他妈给他枪，这下好了，这狗比成了射击clem的帮凶。
3.孕妇， 这就是个长舌妇，burden，以为自己坏了个不知道谁的种就可以成为中心了？大声叫引丧失，根本不关心clem的死活。最后她变丧失了，我就像rick一样，迫不及待给她脑袋来一枪，真是爽

下面是喜爱但有致命缺点的：
1.Luke，本来对luke很有好感的。但是他以为clem被咬了就把clem摔下来，从此路人。期间一直呛他，没帮他说过话。直到最后，冰里面他救了clem，才终于原谅了他。 LUKE其实是个挺矛盾的人，要怪只能怪他太年轻，老一点多一些担当和决断就更好了。
2.Jane，一度很喜欢Jane，对clem很像一个大姐姐。但是她犯了致命错误，最后时刻她本可以不藏孩子。人性不能考验这是多年都说过了的。好人也可能上头干出出格的事，对我来说最后一件事就是一种挑衅。所以Jane你死的不冤，怪不了kenney。要怪怪你自己作死。
3.情妇，就是400天里面打死别人老婆的。她给我的感觉就是weak，不能自己拿主意。最后和叛徒二人组出逃。在clem受伤以后才幡然醒悟。不想再说什么。

reviewText:
Season 2 of the walking dead is probably one of my top 25 games of all time – it is great!

Let me start by saying that I am not a huge fan of the TV show.  But this game is mostly unrelated, so don't let that hold you back.

The graphics are not going to impress you, that's it.  But that's okay too.  TellTale uses a shell shading style that masks the low-end graphics.  But graphics aren't the focus here, story and characters are.

The characters are well developed in this series, perhaps more so than the first.  The story is more exciting.  The game play has shifted to being more story based and less “lets look around for some batteries.”

The largest complaint that I had with the first season was that the game purports to be all about the choices you make and how it affects the world.  However, at the end of season one the ending was always the same, or at least nearly the same.  Yes, some characters may have died and others lived, but in the end you ended up in the same situation.  Season two drastically changes that.  In fact, there are several different endings.  I don't even know how telltale plans to stitch this together into a cohesive season 3 without making 5 different games!

Considering that this game isn't very expensive even at full retail, and it really is one of the best games you can buy, you would be crazy not too.  Who could imagine, our favorite game is one where you play a ten year old girl?

Theres just one point I`d like to point out. Youre playing a adult in a 11 year old body.
Clem isn`t really a child. Not anymore.
Thats not nessesarily criticism i just kinda wanted to say it. I mean I got no idea how it would be to grow up in the apocalypse. So I suppose her beeing grown up in this season isn`t too bad.

reviewText: Season Two is the slow rise and almost certain descent of Clementine. She’s still a child, but she’s no longer innocent, and she knows what she has to do to see another day. It’s heart-breaking in a way to see how time has changed her, to hear the new edge to her voice, to see the new hardness in her eyes and to release in horror the path ahead of her, and what it pertains to. She’s no longer the moral compass, she’s no longer the little girl you try to be a better person around so she can learn from you – she is the culmination of your efforts, and now it’s your job to keep her alive, to keep her safe.\n\nFull Review // http://www.honestgamers.com/12145/pc/the-walking-dead-season-21-all-that-remains/review.html

reviewText: Like all Telltale reviews, by now you should know what you're getting. It's a playable story with limited decisions that you play for the story and good voice acting. So what's up with TWD Season 2? It's good. Not quite as good as Season 1, TWD2 is still a worthy title.\n\nI don't think you can call this game fun". After all
date: the choices are depressing. Your ability to actually change things is exceptionally limited. It's more of an interactive story than a game. Still
recommended: I find this series compelling to play and the narrative gripping. Clem is one of my most favorite characters in all my gaming years (stretching back to Pong). reviewText: A more than fitting sequel to Season 1. Signature Telltale decision making works wonders when incorporated into this kind of plot. There are many dynamic characters, in a wonderful atmosphere. This is a thoroughly enjoyable experience. One thing that particularly stood out was how the decisions in simple conversations brought a personal connection and allowed you to be a part of the relationships you have with characters. Coming from the viewpoint of Clementine, Season 2 seemed to have more opportunity to experiment with that type of decision. Telltale excels in its dialogue as usual. The movement of the plot (including literal movement) seemed to flow better in Season 1, but the emotional affect in breaking that flow makes up for it. It makes me look even more forward to whatever comes next. There's no doubt in my mind that the series will continue to distinguish itself as a really good job at being what it is.

reviewText:
One of my favorite games. I'll probably end up putting as many hours into this as I did Season 1.

[SPOILER ALERT]



PROS-
+ Another amazing story.
+ Story follows Season 1 pretty great.
+ I became emotionally attached to more characters.
+ Kenny ♥
+ Choices from Season 1 are coming back in Season 2.
+ Characters will die or live based on your choices.
+ I cried again.

CONS-
- Way too many possible endings: Clementine can be on her own with A.J. She could have left Jane alive but left her. She could have killed both Kenny and Jane and thus being alone with A.J. Clementine can be with Jane and A.J. at Carver's camp and they can let the family stay. Clementine can be with Jane and A.J. at Carver's camp and turn the family away. Clementine can be with Kenny and A.J. after refusing to stay at Wellington. Clementine can be at Wellington with A.J. after leaving Kenny behind.   There's just too much to make a good continuation that flows well into the next (possible) season.

9.5/10 - Would Cry With All Endings

reviewText: Just like most TV shows, the second installment of this emotional journey through the post-apocalypse can’t keep up with the terrific premiere. Much of the blame lies with the poor cast of uninteresting characters. Some logical errors in the last episode’s story don’t help either. Yet, with a captivating heroine and some spectacular moments of pure terror and horrifying live-and-death-choices, Season 2 is still an easy recommendation for any fan of The Walking Dead. Also, this time the ending actually changes depending on Clementine’s choices.

reviewText:
My opinion for the first episode: If you played Season 1 you will probably enjoy this becouse you can play with Clementine and you can see how much she has changed since the end of Season 1. I really liked the first episode and I can't wait for the other episodes. :)

Episode 2 : I just finished it and it was amazing. It is the best episode so far. It's amazing how you become part of the group so quickly and gain a lot of trust. In this episode you have to make some pretty tough choices though. I can't say even a little without spoiling anything and that is what is great about this episode. It has many things happening in it. Overall it's a great episode and I can't wait for the next one! :)

Episode 3 : In Harm's way sets of pretty strange but soon things start to happend. You rejoin with some fellas and even meet with many more and quickly start working together to escape. Some pretty messed up stuff happens. The end is unexepcted and stays a cliffhanger. Dispite that the episode was very good and intence. I am very excited to see whats coming next :)

Episode 4-5 : The story continues to proceed and more and more dangerous things happend. The group goes north and tries to stay strong and survive. But the problems come from inside the group and thigs start to get messy. You  have to make some pretty tough choices and go though several heartbreaking loses. The game has more than one great endings, all of which are what you would expect from an Tell Tale game. This game and the previous one make some grown people cry like babies and thats what I like about it, it has drama, action and a great dialog.  It's easy to replay and I personally love to play differently every time just to see what the final results will be.
My overall opinion is that this game is outstanding and incredibly touching, deserves to be bought and play atleast several times.It's a must play game like the first The Walking Dead for all gamers.  I definatelly recomend playing it if you haven't played it.

reviewText:

Episode 2 : I just finished it and it was amazing. It is the best episode so far. It's amazing how you become part of the group so quickly and gain a lot of trust. It has many things happening in it. Overall it's a great episode and I can't wait for the next one! :)

reviewText:
I'm a pretty big fan of the AMC series, I played through the first game and did not like it, and for some reason I played through this second season liked it a lot.

This round the game controls never bothered me, I suspect I found the story a less boring cause i pretty enthralled.

The game engine is pretty solid, with a very well written story and great voice acting.  If you're  fan of the series and played the first season and want a little more I would recommend this.

So this is completely out now.  However i think its worth noting.  I personally would suggest not paying for any tale tale game till the game is complete for two reasons.  One you get all the episodes and don't have to wait (that way theres no production issues you end up waiting longer for, and it should be noted that from the relase date of episode 1 to the release date of episode 6 was more than 11 months.   Thats quite a hefty wait for 2 hours of content per episode)  The second reason is its often at a discount price.

reviewText:
Can this game get any better? Just amazing! The Walking Dead Season 2 was as good as the first one, and a bit better. You think choices don't matter so much? This season's ending changes that all!!

Short Summary of Season 2: Clementine makes it to Omid and Christa and they continue surviving together. Clementine encounters another girl in the bathroom and the girl shoots Omid by mistake. A while after we see Christa and Clem around a campfire. We can see that Christa's baby didn't make it. Christa is attacked by a group of survivors and she and Clem split up. Another group finds Clementine and she continues with this group. A lot of other things happen and we see Kenny back, but to know the rest you just have to play!

Opinion: This was really really amazing. The voice acting is very good and the graphics are more improved than season 1. The soundtrack in every ending of an episode is really nice and the choices you've made are showed in the ending like season 1. I wish here was the short summary in the end of season 2, which shows your relationship with the characters just like season 1. The writing of this season was just as good as the first season and the ending was just a big WOW. I mean I bet everyone didn't even know what to do at that point, kill Kenny who is your old friend but he was losing it or kill Jane who is very experienced but made a very wrong action to show what Kenny has come to? I personally choose to kill Kenny. The reason for this is because he was really losing it and he didn't go well with other group members, after all he wanted to be with Katjaa, Duck and Sarita.

Short list of Pros and Cons:
Pros:
- Great Graphics
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=468377446
- Even better story
- Choices get better
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=469787396
- Great soundtrack

Cons:
- ??
Overall Season 2 just amazing, well-written, great graphics and great sound. I recommend it mostly to those who liked Season 1 and like the tv show. If you haven’t played Season 1, you should do that first. I’d rate this 10/10! Played the game? Post down your choices for Episode 5!

reviewText:
Boo! Scary outdoor zombie horror! I didn’t feel scared from the intro screen of trees and a flowing river. Looked more like a multimedia exhibit you see when you go to a national park.  Quiet pines, rolling waters, and piped in elevator music showing how the eco-system works on an LCD screen. Maybe the water doesn't calm you.  It’s slightly unnerving with no people. And the music is in a minor key, making for an unsettling mood. That’s how I played the game pretty much. Unsettled. Fairly intrigued by what may happen next, but not really scared in the least.

This is a storytelling. You weave in and out of decisions that affect the game, yet not the entire outcome.  Then, at the end, you have some tough choices and at least a handful of endings that I can tell.

Episode 1 was my favorite.  It had a dog! Woof Woof Woof.. And it’s that odd ability of a dog to make us smile that Telltale uses to explore how delicate the tipping point between a relationship or betrayal can be.  That theme popped up again and again as I played throughout the chapters.  Nothing was safe, everything could turn with one sudden character decision.  Often, that decision wasn't yours.  That made it less interesting, honestly.  I just waited for some character to screw up because my actions did not affect the final outcome as much as I would have liked.  The scene with Clem doing surgery was gut-wrenching and oh my god - really? - yeeesssh. That was hard to watch let alone do the actual actions to finish the job.
Episodes 2-3 carry into the storyline well, but Nick is a total downer with his whining! After a time I was just wanted to get rid of him.   The only moment I liked was in the shed when he reveals “I had to kill my Mom.  Sounds weird when it comes out, huh?”.  That was a personal opening up..  Probably the best part since  the rest of the scene he is in a drunken stupor. The episodes tied well together, though, and are an enjoyable part of the story of Clem.  There is a weak point with the main action, however.  If you have seen the TV show or read the graphic novels, it honestly doesn't introduce anything new.  And it makes the game a tad boring because of that familiarity.
Episodes 4-5 go into darker territory.  This is heart of darkness stuff where characters don't just lose themselves, they hone a whole new set of malicious skills.  Eventually it comes down to trust and distrust. What constitutes trust in armageddon? Do you trust yourself? Will I survive without my friends?  Would I abandon them or betray them...are they a threat?   Those are the questions that reverberate till the end of the game.

As for the gameplay. There isn't much there.  Really. Rayman Rabbids is harder.  I  only died once and that was because I didn’t see an object fast enough.  Want to shoot a zombie?  Just click whatever, it’s very hard to miss. Telltale made this extremely user friendly, and while it introduces more casual players, it hurts the gameplay for those of us who like more challenge.  I found this arising time and time again.  When I expected a scene to be stressful while running through windows or grabbing equipment before the time was up, it never happened.  Instead you are literally guided through step by step.  I had more challenge playing Spy Fox with my 7 year old.  Perhaps some folks had issues with season 1 causing them to die several times.  But that’s the fun of it!  I missed dying. Tension.  Where is the tension?  I did not feel any.

Visuals are great ( unless you are addicted to anime and want it to look less messy) and I thought the voice acting *made* many of the characters.  Menus are fine. I was able to play at my max of 1080P with no lag on a mediocre system, and the colors change with the episodes which is neat.  Technically, no issues.

It’s a good game all in all.  Just wished I could feel more terror and care more about the characters. In season 1, Lee and Clem had a strong relationship that ultimately claimed Lee’s life.  And it gripped you.  WIth Clem on her own, she bounces back and forth from one set of people to the next.  There aren't any strong relationships with anyone.  Even her strongest friends are undermined by that heart of darkness theme. Can’t feel the love, man. No trust.  Makes for a colder story than season 1.  But still a walking dead story to the bone.  If you enjoy storytelling, this is for you.

Season 1 was absolutely fantastic. I'll admit I cried like a little girl at the end of it.
Season 2 is no exception. Has you on the edge of your seat throuought.

Decisions from Season 1 and the 400 Days DLC are imported if you choose and the events of Season 2 will be altered based on those prior choices. While Season 2 can be started without playing the prior season, I highly recommend doing Season 1 first so that you have a better understanding of what is happening and to have your choices imported rather than being randomly selected for you

On the emotional side:
Sometimes I want  to play through the entire season 2 in one sitting because it's such a great game. But, I can't. It's too hard. Too emotional. So I have to take breaks. Playing more than two sittings of The Walking Dead a day or every other day is very rare because of the strong heavy emotions it causes. And that is just one of the many reasons that The Walking Dead 2 is such a good game; it causes people to feel real emotions: emotions of hate, love, sadness, scardness. Emotions I can not say I've experienced in quite a while, especially in a game?!. If you can not handle that ^ then don't bother playing this game. because that's what it revolvs around.

On a technical side:
Graphics are great, (no surprise there). The camera movements are real, as if you're watching a movie with real people in it. The camera pans in and out and over. Great.
The soundtrack is absolutely fantastic throuought, and if you are into music I definitely reccomend listening to the song at the end of every episode while the credits run; most of the time if not aways, it is related to the episide you just completed.
Voice acting is smooth and powerful with real emotion just like the first season, and unlike any game I have ever seen.

One tiny negative bit I noticed with this Season is that you cannot use your mouse wheel to scroll down the list of responses to the conversations that you are having, like you were able to do in the first Season. You were also able to scroll through your actions of what you do in the game as well so in this season I find myself misclicking something on the screen because I'm used to scrolling, or I find myself nearly missing a timed answer in a conversation because I remember that I can't scroll and have to click.
This minor detail can easily be dealt with , however, because mouse sensitivity on this game (as opposed to Season 1) is much more smooth despite no option to change it, and thus makes choosing one of the choices simple and effortless.

To recap: Fantastically emotional, personal, and powerful. Music is the best. Unbelievably top notch graphics and mouse movement, with a small change in controlls that can be more than easily dealt with and learned.


If you can not already tell, The Walking Dead: Season 2 is just as fantastic as the first Season, and is definitely (besides The Walking Dead: Season 1) the best game I have had the happy pleasure of playing in the longest time.

☆☆☆☆☆ 5/5 stars all the way

reviewText: Instead of giving the shortest review of a sentence that people have seemed to given, I've got an actual review. To anybody who has not played the first season to begin with, I suggest buying that first, or you simply will not enjoy the game to it's best potential. In relation to it's predecessor, the Walking Dead Season 2 is a remarkable game. Telltale seem to have taken their base game and feedback and improved upon it excessively. To begin with, the normal overlay has been edited to be more eye-catching and simple to allow for a balance, to give a fresh feel to the overlays, as well as improving the graphics wildly with this change and even giving revamps of the Season 1 Cutscenes into HD for the starting titles. It has also allowed for more effective animations and less lag within the game, spec wise improving greatly from where the last game knocked off, preventing more of such bugs as walking glitches and cutscene lag. Story wise- Well. You can't say anything. Telltale seems to strike at every moment they can with their games and have yet again woven an encaptivating tale that is absolutely brilliant! I loved the first episode, if a little short and cannot wait for the second. So far, they have expressed many subtle changes that are seen only from the most skilled writers and I cannot fathom how anyone could not enjoy this storyline and how they express the dire situation of a little girl in a post-apocalyptic world. To anybody who reads this- Buy this game and the first. You will not regret it and will be greatly impressed by Telltale's work.

reviewText:
Here we are again, after we've had some time to recover from the emotional rollercoaster that was The Walking Dead: Season One. Just to remind us of how terribly sad we were at the end of that, Season 2 reminds us of our past choices right off the bat. F**k you Telltales!

The Walking Dead is all about hard decisions. It forces dilemma onto you at every chance it gets, cutting deeper and deeper into your moral consciousness, up to a point where you might feel like being a good guy doesn't always work. TWD offers a terrifying insight into human nature by driving humanity to the edge of extinction. And to make things even better, this time you play through the story from Clementine's point of view. The little girl is not so little anymore after the events of the first season and sets out to survive on her own.

After having reviewed the first season, there really is not much to add. It's still a Walking Dead game, it's still a Telltales game. If you enjoyed the first one and are keen to find out how the story progresses, do yourself a favour and pick up Season 2!

reviewText:
**EDIT AFTER COMPLETING THE FULL GAME (SPOILERS)**

This game was truly amazing.

Right from the menu, you immediately feel the suspense and the dread, because you just know something bad will more than likely happen when you get into the Episode.

This season introduced some new mechanics that Season 1 didn't have, such as dragging your mouse to move objects, and choosing a direction suddenly during a high-speed cutscene.

The characters weren't as memorable, as they all progressively died throughout the story in some of the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t ways.  Some choices and the fates of some characters seemed a bit linear, such as Nick, Sarah, and Luke who, regardless of what choice you make, will still die anyway. Which is a shame, because the entire cabin gang had amazing potential to be story changers, but you still either end up with Kenny (who we already know), or Jane (who basically ♥♥♥♥ed you over multiple times).

Also, WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥ HAPPENED TO CHRISTA?!

However, the game kind of redeems itself at the end, where you can end up in 4 different scenarios for the end. I'm very interested in how this will tie into the 3rd Season or TWD: Michonne.

reviewText:
The eagerly anticipated continuation of Telltale Games' Walking Dead series, it picks up where it left off in the first season. We now follow Clementine's journey north after the events that took place in Savannah, Georgia. You play as Clementine and you'll encounter hardships and trials a little girl should never have to face. It'll have you cringing, looking away from your monitor and looking back again with your hands over your head. I've never cringed due to a game before but this just hits the right emotional spots. They made me care for the safety of a video game character. The only other studio, in my case, that has accomplished that was Crystal Dynamics with their Tomb Raider reboot. But there was a difference. I cared about Lara Croft in a pseudo-romantic way. I care about Clementine like how a father cares about a child.

I've only played through the first episode of season 2, and I must say I'm grinding my teeth for more. It's as good as the first season, if not better, and it shows promising potential in areas where it can outdo the first. Kudos Telltale Games, another job well done. Keep at it!

This is arguably their best release yet.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I loved The Walking Dead: Season 1 by Telltale Games, and I also love the show and browsed the much more gore-filled comics. I thought at first that switching the main protagonist from an adult man like the first season, to the little girl that portrayed the daughter-like character would somehow diminish the story somehow and feel like you had less control of situations, but that's not the case: I felt it was much more fun to play as Clem than Lee, in fact.

Telltale likes to tell a great story, and they successfully did so in this season, which I can tell by the, at this time, one episode that's released. You will get a love-hate relationship so strong that you will feel like you are in an abusive relationship with someone you love and still love them anyways. Some of the choices they have make me want to kill them (and they will make you feel) and might have been better if you could somehow change the outcome (like the very beginning, but I guess the story would be much different if it had a split option).

Overall, in season 1 I only cried during the finale of the game (season 1, episode 5), but this season has already made me tear up in just the first episode and I'm not afraid to admit that. Season 1 made you care so much for the character you now control, to the point where they feel real and like family to you, and when you see them in danger you will do whatever you can to fix it.

Even if you have zombie fatigue... Get this... This game is far too good for you to pass up, but you should 100% play season 1 and the 400 days DLC before digging into this one. I cannot wait to see what's in store later on in the season; hopefully I won't have to attack Telltale for ruining it, but I'm sure that won't happen.

reviewText:
8/10 a worthy sequel to The Walking Dead. Season Two of Telltale's fantastic Walking Dead, Season Two lives up to its expectations. Although it is perhaps a little short, the story continues seemlessly into Season 2, as the player is put into the shoes of Clementine. Her development and story here from child to adult is just as emotionally charged as Seaon 1, and is a requirement if you loved Season 1. Characters are again Telltale's niche, and the ones on offer here are just as engaging as in Season One. Only negatives are its play time which edges on the short-side, and the reduced number of puzzels in comparrison to Season One.

+ Continues the fantastic narrative.
+ Again, characters are interesting and dynamic.
+ Clemtine's transition into adulthood is wonderful writing.
+ Morally ambiguous choices which stick with the player.
- A little short in length
- Reduced number of puzzels/hub areas in comparrison to Season One.

reviewText:
Okay, i think it's REVIEW TIME!
... Alright.. that was awful.
Let's get started!

So, i came in ''touch'' with The Walking Dead (s1) and i was like, WOW that Game is frking amazing! but... yeah.. i bought it with the DLC wich means i was so late that all episodes were published and i didn't need to wait!

The Main game was super awesome, it was full of emoticon (from my side) i was like, Happy,Angry,Scared and much more so yeah it is an intense game with a Great story i never played a better game before...

..until the 14th of December 2013 knocked on my Steam account... The Walking Dead: Season 2 with around 15% Price reduction...

Gaben knew he would bring me to pre-order it instant.. i did..

in the same week i played s1 again, just to ..  refresh my mind a bit.

Date: 17th of December
Today was the Offical release of TWD S2 and i woke up with a boner jumped on my chair, started the PC and started the game. BOOM the Menu design, Theme and style was .. special. i can't describe what i felt but it was awesome. i looked at S1 and thought okay.. S1 was awesome but it could've been better... but hey! it's a COMIC STYLE GAME and i love those ''Point and Click'' games!
Whatever.
After starting the first chapter i was like WOW You're there were you ended the story of s1 *AWESOMEEEEE*!
But... After completing the first Episode... i was sad... sad about not beeing able to play it for two month...

After Episode 2 released you see the people from the DLC 400 Days (from S1) which is super cool because... Duh? DLC Content from the 1st game in the 2nd game? ... the game just saves all your decisions and bring them back later to you.

Result:
+ The Game is worth buying if you like Comic-Styled Point and click games with decisions which will come back at you later in the game.
+ If you do something wrong that you will regret in the end the game will punch you in the face with that choice so you know .. you made a mistake and have to live with that.
+ EMOTIONS! (unless you are a Heartless piece of cake)

- The waiting ( which only bothers you if you play since release ^^' )

Right now i'm waiting for S3 and hope it's even better then the 2nd *-*

Please notice i'm from Germany and my english may not ... be the best ^^.
My aim is to write a ''Funny'' and interesting review wich is written in MY opinion and my experience.

reviewText:
[SPOILER FREE]
(Minutes Preceding Full Season Playthrough)

I.... I.... I am unable to find a word to summarise the experience I've had with this game.

Perhaps, combined with Season One, one of the most harrowing emotional roller-coaster rides & engaging game experiences I've had in my lifetime.

The Walking Dead: Season One was a defining title for Telltale Games, bringing forth not only their well-known respect for licensed properties via Point & Click Adventure Games as they've done in the past such as Sam & Max and Back to the Future, but a choice mechanic that outdoes all before it, providing players up to four choices of dialogue or decisions on a timer with the additional option to remain silent or do nothing. Coupled with purely outstanding storytelling & characters, this created a uniquely engaging player-interactive experience.

So what's different about Season Two? Apart from the new story it tells & characters you meet, not a lot. Season Two does what Season One did all over again, at least for me; tell a deeply engaging story with outstanding characters, throwing you tough choices to make at many turns. But what has changed this around I can state:

- The UI has been iterated upon, now making choices & on-screen prompts mouse-cursor driven, and Quicktime Events more precise.
- I seemed to notice a somewhat reduced amount of puzzle-solving compared to Season One. Perhaps not in quantity, but it did seem Telltale Games did take note from the feedback regarding certain puzzle-solving sections from Season One that feedback claimed halted the pace of the game. Maybe the puzzle-solving in Season Two could be better described as more streamlined.
- Quicktime Events have received quite some improvement from Season One, most particularly with moments where you're required to use a weapon are most often much more precise, most commonly with guns, demanding much higher accuracy from the player & really increasing the tension.
- Some certain areas that I must leave for you to find out for yourselves.

All in all, this Choice & Click Adventure" Game is a game I would recommend to anyone & everyone of a mature age looking for a story
date: for this highly player-interactive story is one of the finest I know."

reviewText: Clementine is back, but her life isn't getting any better. The world is still as dark and dangerous as it was before, but this time, she doesn't have Lee by her side. This follow-up to the first season of The Walking Dead comes out with the feels, heavy and hard. If you played the first season, you basically know what you're getting into. For those who haven't (seriously, stop reading and play the first season), this is, at its core, a point-and-click adventure game, but it's the excellent story and writing that elevate this game beyond its genre. If you're a sucker for some great drama and zombies, you can't go wrong with this game.

reviewText: The Walking Dead: Season 2 puts you in control of young girl Clemintine, introduced in Season 1, during the zombie apocalaypse. Along the way you'll meet new companions, fight for your life and make some of the hardest choices you can think of. Your morales will be tested, as you are forced to make decisions that will change the entire experience. Right from the word go you'll be sucked in to the story, feeling for all of the characters and by the end of it you'll wonder where all of your time went. The characters are immensely powerful and when you finally reach the rollercoaster of an ending, you will be left with (in my opinion) some of the toughest decisions in gaming.\nI would HIGHLY reccomend this game, it surpasses the first game and replaces it in the spot of my favourite game of all time. Definetely play the first game first (it's awesome), THEN play this one. It is spectacular. Telltale has delivered the two best games I have ever played, trust me, you don't want to miss out.

reviewText: My problem with the way choices are designed in most current in games is that they hardly ever matter. Most of the time you end up with the same exact scenario no matter what you choose, or you don't feel much of a connection to the characters to care enough in the first place. It is generally just a lazy design option promoted as a feature, imho. Well, I can gladly say that Telltale's Walking Dead" series is a notable exception to that rule - and you'll hate yourself for it.\n\nI played Season 1 on Xbox 360 and loved every bit of it

reviewText:
Here's how I see it: there were two parts of the game that really brought it together, but I can't put it into words how emotionally stimulating they were.
Clementine suturing her arm in Episode 1. Cringe from the physical pain Clementine is going through and it really hits you hard that your darling Clementine is doing this to survive. The whole episode really shows how valorous Clementine is to survive. My personal favorite and most memorable event in the series... and you have to do it yourself; there's no cutscene here.
The final climactic scenario (no spoilers!) really shows how your choices throughout the season all come crashing down, which was interesting while disappointing considering that choices of interpersonal communication among Clementine and other survivors was so small and infrequent juxtaposed to the first season. The finale leaves you to choose what your morals are and ultimately question them or stand by them... hesitantly.Overall, I didn't enjoy it as much as the past season, but that's a scenario you can't recreate and its execution was very well done. But, the few moments I stated above are definitely worth it, and they're worth it only through playing through the entire game. TWD has become more smart in the second installment, and you can become more emotionally involved as the girl you once protected from the new world.
You'll want to question if you can watch Clementine go through what she goes through twice when you replay the game. That's something you don't feel in other games. It's worth something (especially when it's 66% off! Go Steam Sales!)

reviewText:
This is a review-in-progress; only episodes 1-3 are available as of this review

Overall
The Walking Dead: Season 2 game, like its predecessor, is story driven game that is able to create the same sense of mystery, suspense, and action.  Improving on a lot of the systems, you have chances to mend broken relationships and create all new connections with new and old characters as you continue your story through the eyes of Clementine.

Review
The Walking Dead: Season 2 continues a few months after the events in season 1 bringing together a whole new cast of characters with characters from its predecessor where new connections, relationships, and decisions will be formed.  Along with the new characters is a new perspective, where you once playing as an adult who had the strength to deal with the walkers head-on, you now play as Clementine, a young girl who has to use her wits in order to survive.  As with the predecessor, you are in control of your life, making various decisions for good or for bad to help mold Clementine into the character that you want her to be seen as; I feel as though the decisions have been changed for the better as they still impact you, but will not create as drastic of changes as to how each character views Clementine.  Although your decisions can change certain outcomes to an extent, you are generally tied to the story and will be limited in what can actually be changed.  Although the changes may be limited, the story is still full of mystery, suspense, and action to lead the player to want to know what comes next.

Pros
+ Unique story
+ Improved decisions system
+Connect with characters
+ Point and click style

Cons
- Decisions cause limited impact towards the world
- Episodic, can take a month or two for the next episode

reviewText:
The Walking Dead : Season 2? Where do I begin? Well first, I'd like to say that Telltale has once again handled the dark nature of the TWD universe successfully in this installment. The second season of the game in my opinion is another worthy entry of the ongoing franchise.

Like the seasons of the TV show, Season 2 of the game stands out with a different tone and feel than the previous season. In Season 1, we played as Lee Everett, a man given a second chance in life during the zombie apocalypse after he just murdered someone. Season 1 of the game explored the idea of being a father figure to an orphaned young girl, Clementine and trying to raise a child in the beginning of what can be considered a terrible world.

Season 2 evolves from that. In this game, you play as Clementine herself and the world in this state of the game doesn't give a damn if she's a child or not. She's a survivor. It's 16 months after the initial outbreak and other survivors living in the wilderness or broken cityscapes are more hardened and adapted than before. Many are untrustworthy and some are honest, good people. Season 2 brings the character of Clementine from an innocent child to a more mature 11 year old that can handle herself. This makes her feel underestimed by the adults she comes across. So basically, Season 2 is kind of about growing up early.

About the story itself, well I'd say it's well-written for what it is. You get to know a lot about the new characters and older ones that reappear feel more fleshed out than before. You get allies that you may end up hating and encountering a villain that you can somewhat agree with. The only problem with the story is that the 5 episodes are shorter than the first season. But because the story of the second season is so engaging, it makes up for that.

Now is it better than the first season? Yes and No. Unfortunately for the second season, there is a lack of puzzles that were present in the first season. The second season is mainly going through dialogue choices and picking up items to push the story forward. There is also a lot more main character deaths in Season 2 than the first. So if you get attached to one character, don't expect him or her to live long. But then again, this is the Walking Dead. Quick character deaths in all 3 mediums (Comic,TV show, game) are to be expected. However the second season shines in better voice acting, interesting new locations and well-acted villain by the name of William Bill" Carver.  Oh and the combat against walkers are a little bit improved. And one more thing
date: the game has 5 different endings. 2 of them can lead you to entirely different locations. This makes me wonder how unique the first episode of the Third season can start.\n\nAnd is it a good entry to The Walking Dead franchise? Yes. I always felt the game has really been it's own thing. The comic book is about the story and journey of Rick Grimes. The TV show is simply an adaptation of the original comic but also puts it's own spin on various storylines. The game is about Clementine. Lee Everett may have been the original protagonist of the first season
recommended: but it's still about Clementine.\n\nIf there's truly one great thing about TWD : Season 2
hoursPlayed: it's that it grabs you emotionally. It doesn't matter how imperfect the game is
voteText: Telltale cares enough to grab the audience's emotions...\n\nSo yes
helpfulPercent: I recommend this game to all Walking Dead fans.\n\n"

reviewText:
The follow up to the critically acclaimed Walking Dead season 1 game by Telltale, Season 2 keeps you incredibly invested in its story and characters.

You can see my review of season 1 for the usual details, but essentially it's the same old Telltale gameplay. The game is more like an interactive story, focusing more on storytelling rather than moment-to-moment action. Thus, this game is not for you if you're looking for the next innovative, fast-paced, gameplay. If you're looking for a strong story that may or may not leave you emotionally devastated, this is for you.

Like the first game, the gameplay is more of a classic point and click" adventure style game. Throughout the game you'll be able to move around in a very limited area and investigate points of interest by highlighting them with the cursor and using a few different action keys. There are also plenty of quick time events
date: although unlike other games they feel..."right" for the genre rather than out of place and annoying. The gameplay is nothing to be excited about - instead
recommended: it is a means of interaction
hoursPlayed: allowing you as a player to move the story along and make key decisions.\n\nAgain however
voteText: the story is what you're here for. Season 2 picks up after the events of Season 1 and its small DLC
helpfulPercent: 400 Days. You have the option of importing decisions you made in the first game over to new games in Season 2
votesHelpful: although this is not necessary (but I recommend it nonetheless of course).\nYou play as Clementine this time
votesTotal: one of the primary characters from Season 1. The gameplay/story differs a bit because unlike last time
votesFunny: you are now a little girl in a zombie apocalypse. Characters amy underestimate you or treat you differently due to the large age difference
commentsCount: along with giving you as a player a fairly different perspective when it comes to making decisions and interacting with characters.\n\nOther minor details is the appreciated addition of a "move faster" button that you can hold down
column16: so that plodding nature of your character doesn't slow things down too much. In addition
column17: the artwork and graphics seems to have improved compared to Season 1
column18: and there is a greater variety of environments and colours used.\n\nFor those who played through Season 1
column19: Season 2 is definitely worth getting. Aside from continuing the story and potentially crying some more
column20: Season 2 doesn't feel any weaker and continues to hold up Telltale's golden storytelling standards.\n\nIf you haven't played any of the Telltale Walking Dead games (or many of their other games for that matter
column21: such as Wolf Among Us)
column22: I highly recommend this series if you're at all interested in good story and don't mind a much simpler gameplay."

reviewText:
This game takes your feelings and stabs them with a knife. Multiple times. But that isn't meant in a bad way. Just like the first Season of The Walking Dead it is really interesting to see the character developement in this game. This game (aswell as the prequel) are in my opinion one of the greatest pieces of art there is in video game culture at the moment. You may think the zombie theme is overused right now but this game is bringing this scenario to you on a new level. You start to personificate with Clementine and i personally partially sat in my bed thinking about the decisions i made in game even hours after i had played.

I am not quite sure if i like it more than the prequel. The minor bugs that kinda bugged me in the first game aren't to be seen in this game. Still i for myself found it easier to personificate with Lee in the first game, which is probably caused by the fact that i am a near-adult man.

In the end, I think of this game as one of the best sequels i could have imagined. The short time you will need for this game (it took me ~10h) is one of the very few drawbacks. Still a lot of people will find replayability in this game, just to see how other decisions would have influenced the game. If this game is ever on sale (and knowing Steam, it will be)
buy it as well as the first season. It is more than worth the money.

So. All summed up. Telltale never fails to make a story you will still remember in months. And this game is another great example for this.  One of the greatest experiences the gaming market has to offer at the moment.

My personal rating: 92/100

I am already hyped for Season 3.

reviewText:
Fantastic game, rich, deep emotional storyline that stands well on its own or following on from Season 1.

My only critisism of the game would be the way it was released in seperate episode installments weeks apart from each other.  Instead or creating a sense of eager anticipation, buying the game early before all episodes were released, simply created a sense of frustration and annoyance.  If/when Telltale release a Season 3 I shall certainly not be rushing to buy it as soon as its available and will instead wait until all episodes have been created and released.

Apart from this minor critisism the Walking Dead Season 2 is a must have for any fans of this genre.

reviewText: I'm not good in writing reviews, so I'll do my best:\nThe first season of The Walking Dead, following in the footsteps of the comic book and television series, was a deep look at what is left of humanity after the death and zombification of most humans. It followed Lee and Clementine, an unlikely pair, and their group of survivors. The five episodes of the season were less like episodes of a television show and more like episodes of strife; they came upon the videogame playing public like a storm and settled there all year, making us both sad and elated until the tragic completion of the saga. The narrative and emotional weight that The Walking Dead Season 1 dumped on us caused a collective reaction that put the game in the number one spot of many game of the year lists, and since that time we have been awaiting the further adventures of a now-alone Clementine. The Walking Dead Season 2 has arrived to sate our desire, but if the first episode speaks for the rest of the season, it cannot even approximate the capabilities of its predecessor.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Even better than the previous season. To begin, I'm a big fan of Telltale games. The first game I experienced with choices and decisions that can influence the path of the story and with this kind of cinematic-playtime-choice making type of game was Heavy Rain. Obviously, it's not the same game at all but it was kind of like it in some ways. I hated it. When I played the first walking dead game Telltale games made, I completely changed my mind about this type of games. It was simply... awesome. Here's what the game is about.:

The Walking Dead series put you (the protagonist) through a series of events that could occur during a zombie apocalypse, leaving you in a situation where you'll have to make choices to gain trust, to decide what to do in a certain situation, to express who you are and how you'd react to similar events. The story is probably one of the greatest tales I've heard in my whole life. It will play with your emotions and action is always around every corner. This game is fantastic.

I suggest watching a video of a playtrough just to see the first 5 minutes if you don't know what to expect but I strongly recommand both games and a similar game, The Wolf Amoung Us, made by Telltale Games too which is very good.

reviewText: The first season of the Walking Dead was my favourite game to date-and the second season didn't disappoint. Following Clementine, a young girl orphaned and fighting to survive in a world turned to hell, the five-part story explores the human spirit, the bond of love and the limits of human sanity.\nIf you're looking for an open-world, non-linear game focused on exploration-you won't find one here. What you will find is one of the most compelling emotional rollercoasters in the history of gaming,with every decision you make riddled with doubt, angst and uncertainty. I thoroughly enjoyed my time with Telltale's The Walking Dead Season 2, and would highly recommend to anyone looking for a compelling story and a sense of involvement and immersion every step of the way.

reviewText: If you haven't played the walking dead series yet.... What is wrong with you!? It is more than a game. I would call it an an experience! It definitely takes what we know as gaming to a core and flips it on its head. It is an easy game that anyone can pick up even a two year old, (would not recommend) but thats not why we as gamers love this franchise. we love it for the story. we have sympathy maybe even empathy  for poor clementines hard road ahead. she has seen so many people die and now we finally have the chance to make her story. It doesnt matter if the animation isn't the best or you don't like the art style. What matters is that telltale has created the first good choose your own adventure game. when you're tired of shooting up your enemies in a game of cs:go or spamming the click button in a round of dota, what do you play? this masterpiece. so yes is the short answer, play it.

reviewText:
Updated on 19th December, 2014

A worthy sequel of (although not as good as) the original title. I won't say anything about the plot as it's the main course of the game, just know that it's great as always and you'll be in for more than a surprise. Prepare for a crazy ride filled with feelings and tough choices to make, all the time.

If I have to point out two weaknesses of this game with respect to the prequel, I'd say that the episodes are generally shorter 25-30% shorter than those in Season 1, and that exploration and adventuring has been brought down to a minimum in place of a more visual novel-like experience... but in any case, if you liked Season 1 you owe to yourself to play this (and if you haven't played it, go get that game first, you will enjoy this much, much more!)

My vote: 7.5/10

reviewText:
Things just keep getting messier with every episode. I can never decide if I want to facepalm or punch someone because of their actions, but the best part is that the stupidity isn't because of idiot plot but rather idiot characters (just like the ones you meet outside your door!)

Beyond that it's the first game's experience with a couple of superficial quirks. It's a beautiful pseudo-2.5D world that could use a little better AA but still looks gorgeus. You interact with people who are distinguishable and interesting.You make dialogue decisions (and sometimes action decisions) that aren't always so black and white, with the option of saying absolutely nothing always there. You make big decisions that in the end you realize made no difference whatsover, but that little side response you made totally changed the plot's direction an episode later.

Totally worth the money to sit back with the simple controls, and watch the guts fly.

BTW wear goggles.

reviewText:
I just finished this game after 9 hours full of exitement, hesitation and regrets and I still feel a little struck about how things turned out to be in the last episode.

The positive about The Walkind Dead is that the Story-based system is nothing like I've ever played before. Even though you do not much in this game than smashing buttons, move forward, move left, move right or make conversation it never gets boring. The story is amazingly stunning, espacially if you are watching the samenamed TV series.
The game isn't about showing your shooting skills, but about making desicions about trusting people, helping them and keeping care of yourself. The characters are all individual and interesting designed, some more sympathic than others, but with the happenings people's behavior will change in the game.
You are able to make like 15% of the game's plot based on your desicion, e.g. you choose from two people who will you help surviving. That doesn't sound that much, but it's alright- to be honest, it was enough burden for me to burry ;) The music fits the atmosphere just fine and the system that shows you how often people made the same desicions as you did is a nice feature too.

To name the bad aspects as well I have to admit that you really have to like the graphic style. It is kind of comic based and I really had to get used to it, but in the end I am glad it looked like this (some brutal scenes might have scared me a lot more if it had been a more realistic graphic).
The game isn't that cheap for what it offers, but I bought it while it was on sale and I'd totally do again.
At the end of every episode there are credits that can't be interrupted. This might be annoying if it wasn't for the beautiful, sad music that made you think about what happend in the episode.

All in all I totally recommend this game for anyone who is into story-based games, the TV series, comic style graphics or anyone who just wants to test his ethical oppinions. Enjoy!

reviewText: Although Season Two begins with a bit of a sour taste left in your mouth from the end of Season One, it really steps up its game as it progresses. The animation has improved visibly since the first installment, and the voice actors have all remained consistent while still showing a believable amount of maturation for their characters. The storyline is excellent, and the choices you make affect the outcome more than they did the first time around. The controls have become slightly more complex as well, adding another element to your gameplay. Worth the buy, but I would highly recommend using a controller.

reviewText:
Mere words cannot express how much I love this game. This story, these characters, everything draws you in and immerses you into a dangerous world where you truly feel that all hope is lost. Some parts will make you laugh, or simply crack a smile, while others will send tears running down your eyes as you witness the death of yet another beloved character...yet another comrade taken by things far worst then zombies. If your a fan of season one then you should need no convincing! Season two is just as good or I dare say even better then the first, and this is coming from someone who is only on episode 2 of the second season, and already its been an emotional roller coaster. If your a fan of the show then I will just be blunt with you, in my honest opinion, this game is 10x better then the show is or most likely ever will be. It might just be a game, but the characters are just so much more interesting, you feel drawn to them and when one of them is forever silenced not only do you feel sadness, but a burning anger as well.

Your choices mold the story, you decided who to befriend and at times who lives and who dies. The decisions are hard, the consequences even harder, but in the end it all comes down to survival of the fittest, and as you steer young Clementine through this dangerous world and watch her grow into a young women you'll start to look back on your past decisions with regret. The fact that once you make the choices their set in stone is what makes the game so fun, just like in realy life once you make a choice there is no going back.

EDIT: After finally completing the game I must say that the ending was very satisfying indeed, you actually get to decide how it ends unlike the first one where what happens at the end of the game is set in stone. As a man, I'm not afraid to admit that tears were shed towards the end of this game, and the fact that a videogame can make me shed tears at all makes this one of the best games out there in my book.

reviewText: The long awaited sequel to the acclaimed Telltale adventure, The Walking Dead: Season 2 offers just as much excitement and emotion as its predecessor. The game now allows players to take the role of the beloved Clementine, whom we saw abandoned at the close of Season 1. Clem is now older and more hardened to her cruel apocalypse life. Players quickly meet new characters (friends and foes) that have many mysteries behind them. Though at first it is hard to accept those that feel like replacements for our lost allies of the first game, after Episode 1, I found I had warmed up to this interesting bunch. The new threat of a captivating villain known as Carver paralells events which have occured throughout the universe before. Although it seems like a repeat of the evil group" trope we've come to know

reviewText: If you buy any game as a avid player or as a bit here and a bit there player, you have to buy this game along with the first one. This game no wait this story is one of the best that I have ever spent money on and it was worth all of it. You will hate characters love characters no matter what choices you make. This story will test your humanity with every move you make. It will make you hate yourself and feel great when you do that one thing that makes things look better for everyone well being. It will toug the heart strings and sucker punch you before you know it. Ask anyone you know that has played this and if they don't say but it as soon as you ask then they are crazy. This whole story will keep you on the tip of your seat the entire time. Now for your sake and Clems sake buy this when you can and don't spoil it for yourself or anyone you know. 10/10\n
